name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 14 November 2019.

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, let us take our place. One in three women or girls experience physical or sexual violence in their lifetime. The victims are not statistics. A woman who is the victim of violence suffers her all her life. Ladies and gentlemen, we must break our silence and put an end to shame and impunity. Gender-based violence is violence against human rights. It is also one of the main obstacles to the empowerment of women and girls and the achievement of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. It has devastating consequences for the victims but also for our societies. It is our common task to put an end to violence against women and girls. It is a task of every moment, of every day, a task that must involve indignation but also action. Action to ensure gender equality, to prevent violence, to protect victims and bring those responsible to justice. Action to achieve global and coordinated policies, involving different actors and making a difference to the women and girls of our time. It is time for all Member States and the European Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument to prevent and combat violence against women and girls. On the occasion of the 2019 International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, we will join the Orange the World initiative, bringing to light the stories of women and girls looking to a brighter and more violence-free future. This evening the building of our Parliament will also be orange as a sign of solidarity with all the women who have been victims of violence, to send a message of peace and willingness to act, to defend our values, the values of the European Union, and that is why I propose, ladies and gentlemen, a minute's silence in memory of all the women who have been victims of violence. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

text: Also on Tuesday, the GUE/NGL Group called for the Council and Commission statements on the unacceptable conditions under which animals are subjected during transport to third countries to be added this afternoon, following the Commission's statement on the crisis of the WTO appeal body. name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, yesterday there was a tragedy in the Black Sea: the overloaded ship Queen Hind capsized shortly after it had left the Romanian port of Midia. Of the 14 600 sheep on board, only 33 survived this disaster. The fate of the remaining 14 567 sheep can be guessed: they drowned after a long and fearful death struggle. Foreign ships, such as the Queen Hind, are increasingly docking in European ports. They transport millions of animals in horrific conditions to Saudi Arabia, the Persian Gulf and other distant destinations. European animal welfare rules are ignored. These transports are cruel, last for weeks and take place on converted cargo ships that are sometimes up to 50 years old. The older the ships, the more likely these tragedies are to occur.  We can no longer stand by. The export of live animals to countries outside the EU must now stop. Please show compassion and support the request to have a debate on this. Thank you in advance, also on behalf of the animals.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, ‘clearly, planet Earth is facing a climate emergency’. This statement was released on 5 November by 11 000 scientists from 153 nations. The climate crisis is accelerating faster and more severely than anticipated. The statement I quoted is in line with the recent special reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), according to which human-induced warming has already raised 1° Celsius above pre-industrial levels and is increasing at approximately 0.2° Celsius per decade. By the end of the century, based on the current climate policies implemented worldwide, temperature is projected to rise by 3.1° to 3.7°. It’s clear that progress so far is insufficient and efforts should urgently be stepped up. The United Nations indicates that the nationally determined contributions (NDCs) submitted by parties to the Paris Agreement collectively fall far short of what is required to limit the rise of temperature to 1.5°. The overall situation is rather bleak, yet there are some encouraging signs including global birth rate, investments in solar and wind power and fossil fuel divestments. Moreover, there is growing awareness and concern about global warming and its effects. All over the world, active civil society coalitions, citizens and the youth in particular are calling for decisive action that will determine the future of the planet and humanity. We have heard their appeal to implement the paradigm shift to climate-proof the circular economy, that our economies and societies urgently need in order to mitigate the most catastrophic consequences of climate change. The climate action summit in September demonstrated the political will to step up collective ambition. It resulted in a number of major announcements by governments and private-sector leaders, including at EU level, on the reduction of greenhouse gas production, climate finance and carbon neutrality. Madam President, Honourable Members, as regards the Paris Agreement, the EU is preparing its long-term strategy for greenhouse gas emissions reductions that will be submitted to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change by 2020. Most Member States agree with the objective of climate neutrality in the EU by 2050, and several of them have already set national targets contributing to that goal. The European Council is committed to finalising its guidance on the EU’s climate-neutral vision before the end of this year, with a view to reaching an agreement between all Member States. The road to climate neutrality in the EU will affect everyone and will require efforts from all sectors of the economy. It’s therefore essential that the transition must be just and socially balanced and that no one is left behind. It is equally essential to scale up their investment in research and development, if the EU wants reap the opportunities in terms of growth and employment that climate neutrality will trigger. The EU has taken the lead in implementing the Paris Agreement. We are set to over-achieve our 2020 20% reduction target. The climate and energy legislative framework is designed to enable us to reach the 2030 target. That involves a reduction of domestic greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% below 1990 levels. Actually, thanks to Parliament’s, the Council’s and the Commission’s good cooperation, we were able to increase the ambition level up to -45% while finalising climate 2030 files. The EU has successfully decoupled economic growth from emissions. From 1990 to 2017 the EU’s economy grew by 58%. Total greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 22%. A recent report by the European Environment Agency indicates that the EU’s total emissions decreased by 2% in the last year. This brings the total reduction to 23.2% below 1990 levels. By promoting this positive example, we can inspire all parties to the Paris Agreement to raise the global ambition. It is in that spirit that the EU actively prepares for COP25. We call on all parties to update their NDCs and to increase their clarity, transparency and understanding. COP25 will test the willingness of all parties to finalise the implementation of the Paris agreement. The rule book was almost totally agreed in Katowice last year, with the important exception of the rules on voluntary cooperation in Article 6. As agreed by the Council on 4 October, the EU is committed to working with all parties to develop robust and comprehensive rules on voluntary cooperation. The EU’s core position in this respect is to agree on rules on internationally transferred mitigation outcomes that encourage ambition and progression in NDCs, guarantee environmental integrity, avoid double counting and provide for the closure of the Kyoto Protocol Mechanisms. Finally, the fight against global warming needs adequate financial means and resources which are key for increasing global ambition and for facilitating the transition to climate-smart economies. The EU is the world’s biggest climate finance contributor. The contributions of the EU and its Member States exceed EUR 21 billion annually and fulfil their commitment towards the mobilisation of USD 100 billion per year by 2020 through to 2025, as part of the collective developed countries goal. The Council has recently adopted conclusions on climate finance. The Council reaffirms the commitment of the EU and its Member States to ensure that the deliberations set a new collective quantified goal from the floor of USD 100 billion per year prior to 2025. The deliberations are to take place in November 2020 with the aim of making global financial flows consistent with the long-term goals of the Paris agreement. The Council also stresses the importance of the need for a wider variety of funding sources and for a broader range of contributors. As you can see, we have an important and dense COP25 ahead with a lot of items to be discussed. Let me assure you that the European Union will play an active role in these discussions.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to participate in this timely and topical debate on the pressing issue of climate and environmental emergency, while we look ahead to preparations for the upcoming 25th Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, in Madrid, led by the Government of Chile. Climate change and the environment are a top priority for our citizens, and in particular for our young people. Science is clear: each year matters, each choice matters, each half a degree matters. It is of the utmost urgency that we act now. Fires have raged from the Amazon to Siberia; heatwaves, droughts and cyclones are affecting billions of people throughout the world. Climate change and the biodiversity losses are already affecting critical life systems on earth, threatening the livelihood of many. Together with you, we have put in place a comprehensive climate and energy framework and have delivered on our objectives in the Circular Economy Action Plan. But we need to do more. We need much, much stronger action, as science and our youth keep reminding us. The European Union is strongly committed to continuing an ambitious and urgent action to effectively address the interdependent environmental and climate crisis in an integrated manner – globally. This is essential for sustainable development, poverty eradication and delivering on all of the Sustainable Development Goals. On the environment side, we need to engage all partners in bringing about the ‘transformative change’ that is necessary for our planet’s survival. We must make 2020 a landmark year for climate, nature and ecosystems, including through an ambitious post-2020 global biodiversity framework to be adopted at the Conference of the Parties under the Convention for Biological Diversity in Kunming, China. On climate, we must continue our efforts and accelerate our action in the European Union and globally. Four years ago, the international community celebrated the Paris Agreement as a game changer. And last year we agreed on the Katowice Rulebook – the first ever universal transparency and accountability system applicable to all, with in-built flexibilities for those who genuinely need it. Both Paris and Katowice are landmarks for multilateralism and a true testament of global resolve and solidarity.  Looking ahead to Madrid, completing the work on making the Paris Agreement work well in practice must be our first collective objective. In this regard, a key topic for COP25 is the single element of the Rulebook left outstanding in Katowice: the guidance on voluntary cooperation and market-based mechanisms under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. Securing a meaningful outcome for market measures under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement is important for the European Union. If we do it right. Compromises that put environmental integrity at risk are not acceptable to us.  The decisions that we take at COP25 must prevent the double counting of emission reductions, and to achieve this the rules must account comprehensively for all uses of international carbon markets. The decisions we take in Madrid should also create strong incentives to reduce emissions now and in the future, and this means avoiding the use of past emission reductions to undermine current and future ambition. The new mechanism under Article 6.4 should avoid the weaknesses of the Kyoto Protocol Mechanisms.  Second, our other substantive priority for COP25 is the successful review of the Warsaw International Mechanism on Loss and Damage: to stimulate practical ideas that help people on the ground to take effective action to avert, minimise and address loss and damage, particularly for vulnerable communities in their specific situations. Third, the European Union attaches great importance to stakeholder engagement in COP25, particularly on Oceans. The Chilean Presidency has made this a top priority for this ‘Blue COP’. But in Madrid we must begin looking at the bigger picture, and how we – and all other parties to the Paris Agreement – respond to the increasing request from citizens everywhere in the world for more and more decisive action. We believe that in Madrid we must continue to incentivise, support and accelerate action from all actors towards the objectives of the Paris Agreement. The European Union will continue to do its homework on this and will continue to lead by example. Next year we will update our nationally determined contribution, to make it clear that the full implementation of our legislative framework will effectively enable us to overreach the current commitment of ‘at least 40%’. Around 45% reductions are estimated by 2030. Yet this is not the whole story. We will make it clear that the European Union is irrevocably committed to a path that will lead us to do our full part under the Paris Agreement, and will offer others an effective model to do their part. The European Union will be at their side, offering full cooperation and support. European Union leaders have committed to finalising their guidance on the objective of climate neutrality by the end of the year, in good time for the long-term strategy to be submitted to the UNFCCC in early 2020. The objective remains to create a modern, competitive, prosperous and climate-neutral society by 2050. At the same time, the demands of our citizens have spurred the European institutions to look again at what we need to do already in the 2030 perspective. The next European Commission has already announced that it will work in earnest to raise the European Union ambition higher than 40% or 45% greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2030. For the European Union this is a continuous process that can only stop when the objectives of the Paris Agreement are fully reached. Our efforts in this direction will continue well beyond our borders. The European Union and its Member States remain the largest contributor of public climate finance to developing countries, including to the multilateral climate funds, and have contributed EUR 21.7 billion in climate finance for 2018, which is double the level of 2013.  Yet we all know that public finance alone will be insufficient to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement. Therefore, it is crucial to make swift and ambitious progress to make all finance flows consistent with the Paris Agreement. To this end, following its Action Plan on Financing Sustainable Growth, the Commission launched in October the International Platform for Sustainable Finance in order to deepen international cooperation and, where appropriate, coordination on sustainability approaches and initiatives for the capital markets. At the same time, we will continue to mainstream climate policies in all our international relations and in our development cooperation. We will continue to persuade others to follow the path of climate neutrality as soon as possible in the second half of this century, as science incites all of us to do, and we will offer all our partners dialogue, cooperation and support in doing so. Let me conclude by saying that we should all offer our strong support to the Chilean COP25 Presidency with a view to a successful outcome in Madrid.  At the end of this session, let me take the opportunity to thank you for your exceptional collaboration over the last years. It has been an honour to serve in the Juncker Commission, and a special privilege to work with such dedicated parliamentarians here in the European Parliament. I am at the same time humbled by all that we have achieved in these past five years, and proud of the leadership that the European Union and its institutions have shown, at home and abroad, and in multilateral fora. Together, we have achieved historic milestones, from the adoption and ratification of the Paris Agreement, through to the conclusion of a comprehensive legal framework on climate and energy in the form of the 2030 legislation and the Clean Energy Package. All that with exceptional political consensus and support in both the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers. This is exactly the European Union at its best, an excellent example of European Union added value for our citizens.  What we have achieved puts in place a solid foundation for the next decades to enable us to go further and faster, as demanded by our European citizens, because, despite all we have done, alone it is not enough. And again, Europe and its institutions must take the lead in going forward. I will remain your strongest supporter as you embark on this important task in the years ahead.

name: Pascal Canfin
text: Author. Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are a few days after the Venice climate disaster, a few weeks after Donald Trump confirmed the withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement, and we are now a few hours away from the election, which will be held in two days, of the new European Commission, which has made the Green Pact - action to combat climate change and biodiversity. We are also a few days away from COP 25. So there is no better time to have this debate and declare a climate and environmental emergency in Europe. We are in Strasbourg on Monday evening and on Thursday we will have to decide on the state of climate and environmental emergency. I would like to say today to the European citizens who are following our debates that as we speak, we are not sure that on Thursday this Parliament will vote on the climate and environmental emergency. Yet several national parliaments have done so: the United Kingdom, Ireland, France, Portugal, Austria and others, with very different political majorities. I think it would be incomprehensible to European citizens, especially young Europeans who travelled massively in the European elections to make a strong voice heard and say: 'Don't let us down! We are 20 years old today; in 2050, we will have lived, we will be 50 years old, and you want to leave us a world with a global warming to three, four or five degrees? If we do not want this and we want to send this message to our children, to all our children, including mine, we will have to vote in three days for the climate and environmental emergency. It would be, once again, an extraordinary occasion if the European Parliament were the first continental parliament to say :'Europe is the first continent in the world to declare a state of environmental and climate emergency'. It would be an extraordinary opportunity; it would be an extraordinary message that we would of course send to our European citizens, but also to the citizens of the rest of the world. After the message that Donald Trump sent them, which basically meant saying, "Go and be seen!", we have to send the exact opposite message. We are interested in them, we are interested in the climate issue for our citizens and for all the citizens of the world, because - as was mentioned today - the first donor of official development assistance is the European Union, and we can be proud of that. So this message is symbolic. Obviously, it's not going to change everything overnight, everyone is aware of that. But if we could not send it, then the symbolism would be terrible. I therefore call for the responsibility of every Member of this Parliament. On Thursday, we will have to vote as widely as possible. It is not a partisan issue, it is not a matter of small partisan politics, it is a question of collective responsibility. We must vote - as other national colleagues have done - for a climate and environmental emergency. In the short term, we also have a resolution on COP 25 and the new European Commission which will take office in a few weeks. One of the great messages that we must send in this resolution, which I am sure we will send it, is to reduce our own CO2 emissions well beyond the current targets that Commissioner Caete has reminded and which are far below what science requires us to do. So what we need to do is reduce our greenhouse gas emissions in 2030 by 55% compared to 1990. That's what science asks us to do, it's not what emotion dictates to us, it's not what irrationality would ask us or would demand of us, it's what scientists are asking us to do, and I think that as politicians of the left, right or center, we have to listen to this scientific message and listen to the message of young people and listen to the message of young people. , and thus support, in the resolution for COP 25, this requirement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55%. Colleagues, I hope that on Thursday we will live up to the history before us.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Let me begin by thanking our Commissioner Miguel Arias Caete. He had been very, very critically observed at the beginning of his mandate. He quickly convinced me that he was the right person. And thank God many who initially fought him also realized that he was a fighter for climate protection in Europe and worldwide. Thank you for your work, Commissioner. We must act urgently to prevent climate change from becoming extremely dangerous. We are in danger of reaching tipping points, which will cause climate change to affect itself and our children and grandchildren will no longer be able to stop climate change, even if they make such a great effort. I think we are in agreement on this in the vast majority. Now there is this second resolution. Pascal Canfin spoke of "urgence" in French. In French, I agree that in German the term 'emergency' – that is a possible translation – has a very negative tone, it has to do with panic, it also has to do with the fact that in the Third Reich in Germany democratic rights were overridden under this term. That is why I would rather speak of an 'urgent' way. We need urgent and sustainable action. We don't need to panic, we really need to do something and take the rest of the world with us. If we could agree on this, I would be very, very happy. Then we will vote here together on Thursday.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I too would like to thank Climate Commissioner Cañete for his cooperation over the years, and not least the work you did on the ETS negotiations. I would like to commend the cooperation we had there. Ladies and gentlemen, ahead of today's debate, new figures have just been presented showing that the concentration of climate gases in the atmosphere was the highest ever last year. It is very serious. Since the Paris Agreement was signed in 2015, the heat records have been tight. And what we're seeing right now is that our house is literally on fire and every day we don't turn things around, this fire is going to be harder and harder to put out. For our planet, this is fatal; we need to work quickly and to understand the seriousness. We have a climate emergency in Europe and the rest of the world, and as elected representatives we have a responsibility to understand this seriousness and act accordingly. The Paris Agreement is the framework we have to deal with, but we see right now that the Member States are not doing enough to meet the necessary commitments. Commitments should be multiplied in order to comply with the Paris Agreement. As things stand right now, we are moving towards over three degrees of warming with temperature increases at that level. As a Parliament, we have a hugely important role now in the run-up to the Madrid climate summit, and I have to say that it is the A and O that everything is pulling in the same direction in the world. We cannot allow instruments that are even counterproductive to the efforts needed to bring down global warming. EU Member States still have fossil fuel subsidies worth an average of €55 billion each year. This is completely unreasonable and something that our group wants to put an end to. We must also ensure that the international community lives up to the Paris Agreement, that the Member States really make the necessary commitments, the national commitments, and that also applies to our own Member States. Colleagues, our house is on fire. Let us, with joint efforts, put an end to that fire and save our planet.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, Best Secretary of State Tiilikainen. When we vote on the resolution on Thursday, my fifth grandchild Iris Elvira turns nine years old. So I owe something to my six grandchildren for the decades to come. For this reason, when we are discussing the objectives between us, it was quite easy to say that we are sticking to 55%. It is the least we can do for the generations to come.  It will also present the Member States with serious challenges. We know that the key that existed, for example for burden-sharing, made tougher demands on Finland than on Bulgaria. When we raise the target, it will also be raised for everyone. So it is around 55% that we are now fighting, and that is the objective we must stick to.  I would then like to conclude by thanking Commissioner Cañete for his good cooperation over the five years. And so I hope that the Finnish Presidency will also save my grandchildren.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, thank you yet again for this important debate on climate. Indeed, it’s going to be historic. If we are going to call the climate emergency this Thursday, as the European Parliament, we then have to follow up. That’s the crucial point. We can declare climate emergencies, but the people on the streets are not asking us for declarations, they are asking us for actions. At the European level, unfortunately – and it’s not your fault – when we go to Madrid, the EU will come empty—handed. We can’t even say that the 2050 climate neutrality target will be embraced by the EU, for example, because in the Czech Republic, a Renew Prime Minister is not signing up to that. That needs to change instead of declarations. What needs to change is that this House needs to change its own behaviour.  So, Finnish Presidency, can you now put forward a question to all the Heads of State, asking that we finally stop the nonsense of the travelling circus of this European Parliament. Then we will be taking action. To the Commission – I know it will not be you, it will be the new Commission – it’s about time that this climate law talks about urgent actions and not just 2050 again. We have had enough of empty declarations. We need action.

name: Sylvia Limmer
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For me, the resolution on COP 25 is a document of embarrassing intellectual meagerness, not only because of the ridiculous assertion in paragraph 33 that the global action of the next ten years would have an impact on the future of humanity over the next 10 000 years: climate rescue, in other words. A climate that, indisputably, has been changing drastically for millions of years, even without the intervention of the people. This is now to be frozen at the stand of Anno Domini 2015.  Environmental protection is also only synonymous with climate protection. Catastrophic environmental damage caused by the degradation of rare earths: no matter. Lead and cadmium in solar panels, child labour in Congo, health consequences of infrasound, disastrous land use, soil sealing, low-species energy crops, monocultures, sulphur hexafluoride in wind turbines – a 24,000 times more effective greenhouse gas than CO2 – no matter. The end seems to justify the means here, too. So the next 10 000 years. If we allow this apocalyptic policy of terror of the new green totalitarianism to prevail, then we do not even need to think about the next ten years.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I, too, would like to thank you very much for your cooperation, for your contribution to the adoption of the Katowice rulebook, because the Katowice Summit was important in describing the principles for the adoption of the Paris Agreement. The previous ers call for sincerity, so let us be honest that we need a just climate transition that does not exclude anyone. However, the preliminary materials indicated by the Commission speak only of eur 5 billion for nearly a few dozen so-called coal regions, for nearly 50 coal regions. These are really symbolic measures. You say that our citizens expect concrete action. So I encourage the two seats of the European Parliament, however, to unite and create one place where we will work and sit. Then you will not be a hypocrite.

name: Manuel Bompard
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to the United Nations, the world has reached a new record high in greenhouse gas emissions in 2018. This is another missed opportunity, because scientists tell us that these emissions will have to decrease from 2020 if we are to comply with the Paris agreements and thus limit the rise in temperature to 1.5 degrees. So we have two years to turn things around, two years so that our children, our grandchildren, these young people who are mobilizing all over the world, can simply live tomorrow on this Earth. For it is indeed the survival of the human species that is at stake. It is time for our Parliament to proclaim the obvious: we are in a state of climate and environmental emergency. Look at the time that's running out! There is so much to do: let's plan the energy transition to reach 100% renewable energy by 2050; let us turn the page on free trade by rejecting new trade agreements and, on the contrary, promoting the economic relocation of activities; Let us radically change the common agricultural policy to build the ecological agriculture of tomorrow; Let us introduce the green rule rather than the golden rule so that each of our decisions is now made in the light of the climate emergency; let's act quickly before it's too late.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a new record for greenhouse gas emissions for 2018, the WMO tells us today. Globally, gas concentrations continue to increase rather than decrease. The message that the European Union must therefore necessarily take to COP25 in Madrid is only one: more needs to be done, because what we are doing is not enough. Think of the transport sector, a sector that has increased its emissions since 1990 and, even more paradoxically, there are no binding emission reduction targets in aviation and maritime transport. According to the IMO, however, maritime emissions could even increase by up to 250 % by 2050. That is simply unacceptable! So what solution? For example, to create and establish areas for monitoring emissions of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide, as they already exist in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea but not in the Mediterranean Sea. The creation of an ECA area in the Mediterranean, in addition to reducing SO2, CO2, NO2 and consequently particulate matter and ozone, would prevent 10 000 premature deaths by 2050. The costs would be largely offset by the benefits of such an action.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Madam President! In fact, I am convinced that this Parliament has the willpower to deal with climate challenges and to view them as very urgent. If we are to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement without stalling our society, our democracy, and limit our freedom and opportunities to live the life we want, and if we are to hand the planet in a better position to our descendants than we were given it by our ancestors, then we must use the strongest muscle in society's body, namely the market. The market that keeps the backbone of millions of jobs upright as a vital prerequisite for Europe's nations and families.  Therefore, the debates are filled up to COP25 with discussions on how the market logic can best contribute to reducing CO2 globally. With socialist, planned and restrictions on freedom, or with civic respect for entrepreneurship and innovative cooperation between researchers and companies. The voters in Europe have put us together in Parliament and in the Council in a way where it is crucial that we can work together. That is why I would really like to ask the Council and the Commission how you want to pick up and ensure maximum momentum, with the EU showing the rest of the world how Europe is capable of delivering the most sustainable CO2 reduction by virtue of the way we use our market.

name: Mohammed Chahim (S&D).
text: Mr President, today we are making a promise and sending out a signal. A promise, initially to ourselves, and a signal to the rest of the world: Europe is going to take responsibility and show leadership for a better climate. Solidarity will be at the heart of all our future climate policy. First of all, solidarity between rich and poor. There are more than 50 million Europeans who are struggling to pay their energy bills. This can and must be done differently. That is why we must distribute the costs and revenues of this transition fairly. We can't leave anyone behind. Secondly, solidarity between the different sectors in our economy. We now have an opportunity to green our economy, to reform our economy. Doing nothing is not an option. We need to create jobs that are ready for our future. Finally, solidarity with other places in the world. Europe cannot solve the climate problem alone. We need to look beyond our borders for ideas, actions and solutions.  With this resolution, the European Parliament is sending a signal: Europe is ready to take responsibility and show leadership. That is why we must declare a state of emergency on Thursday, because it is essential to stay below 2 degrees together. We must stop subsidising fossil fuels. We want a fair CO2 price for flying and shipping. There will be an investment fund to reform our economy and make the transition affordable for everyone. I am proud of this resolution. It is time for greater ambition, socially just plans and more political leadership. That is why I am voting in favour of this resolution on Thursday and i am asking you to do the same.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules))

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Lord, I would like to ask you, if you say 'no' to fossil fuels so firmly, if you also want to reject energy from gas and energy from an atom, then please tell me what you want to replace that energy?  The most important issue is social justice and energy exclusion. In the European Union, nearly fifty million people suffer from energy poverty. They can no longer afford to heat or cool their apartments depending on where they live. Do you notice the protests of yellow vests in France, the growing problem of energy poverty?

name: Mohammed Chahim (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, it is very important to invest the money we have together in a good way. It is not appropriate, especially now with the climate crisis, to continue subsidising fossil fuels. We think you should start investing that money in a different way. One of the ideas we have on this – an idea that Frans Timmermans has also brought here – is to invest in a new hydrogen economy that will not only provide us with sustainable energy, but will also give us as Europe an economy that is future-proof.  On the second point, it is precisely when it comes to affordability that we want everyone to be in this transition. It is very important to help people who are now unable to pay their energy bills to make their homes more sustainable. Then you create a win-win situation for ecology, for humans, for the wallet.

name: Fredrick Federley (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Europe needs to do far more than we do today. Although we took a great deal of steps forward during the last parliamentary term under the leadership of Commissioner Cañete, we can still see that most of the cars sold today are still fossil-powered. We are seeing an increase in energy demand year by year, and it is still not the case that renewables cover the increased demand, but it is still the fossil energy that covers the greatest of our energy needs. 73% of all energy in the European Union is still fossil. This means that we need to make efforts to get more of the renewal, to rethink the transport sector and to rethink the construction sector. But we also have some easy goals where we haven't even started working. I am glad that you are all wearing clothes in here today, but it also means that you contribute to 12% of global emissions of CO2. We haven't even managed to get a recycling system for clothing fibers. We have not been able to get a recycling system to reduce food waste, which means that approximately 30-35% of all food produced in our fields in the EU is really just thrown into the bins. So we still have a lot to do at home. But of course we will do more together, also globally.

name: Pär Holmgren (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As a meteorologist, I have been following the climate issue for about 30 years now. I think I have been following the climate policy debate for almost as long. It is fantastic that I notice that there is now finally an awakening in political groups other than the Green one. The only problem is that climate policy is constantly lagging behind climate research. We are talking about a 50-55% reduction in emissions by 2030, when there are scientists today who say that even 100% reduction in emissions by 2020 would not guarantee that we will reach the Paris climate targets.  It's great that we're starting to talk about a climate emergency. But then we must also fill it with content. Of course we're going to get rid of subsidies for fossil sand, we're going to think about transport, food and much more. Above all, however, we must live up to much, much tougher emission targets in 2025, 2030 and all the way forward, so that we in Europe take the lead.

name: Catherine Griset (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement died before it had lived because of the programmed failure of its funding and its objectives. After the US withdrawal, it becomes impossible for Europe to mobilise the resources needed for the Green Fund. What will happen to the 1 trillion euros of the Green Pact? The COP will also have to review its climate ambition in the face of non-compliance with commitments in Asia and Africa, two regions far more polluting than we are. Europe's blindness, however, is more serious in the globalist vision of UN experts and NGOs - in defiance of the only possible path, namely local and national cooperation - in the instrumentalization of climate diplomacy for the purpose of interfering against the sovereignty of States and in the response to the deadly danger of climate migration announced against a background of environmental disaster. (The speaker refuses a question blue card from Robert Rowland)

name: Pietro Fiocchi (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am an engineer and an industrial entrepreneur. I have this intimate need to understand how to reach goals. We all agree that we need to do something about climate change, but how? My team and I analysed, for the best part of two months, how to reach the Paris Agreement goals and we could not find a good technical answer. We then asked everybody and the only answer we got was that we raise taxes and then see what we do. This is not good. Also, nobody commented on the fact that the US, India and China are not doing anything about this and are therefore making the European efforts totally useless. Now we want to raise the bar. This is problematic because we, as the European Parliament, have a moral duty to explain to EU citizens how we intend to reach the goals, and how we intend to do this without killing their livelihoods and the economy.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Europe has a huge climate debt. In the global North, we contribute far more to climate breakdown with our history of emissions, yet we refuse to take radical action, even though we have a disproportionate amount of the world’s wealth. We cannot fix a problem caused by capitalism with more capitalism. The truth is, climate change isn’t caused by people, it’s caused by an economic system that drives inequality and rewards environmental destruction. We cannot fix this with neo-liberal policies. It’s not about encouraging consumers to make environmentally friendly choices; we need an emergency-level response outside the framework of encouraging behaviour change. We need a 70% reduction in emissions by 2030: anything less, and it means that we don’t actually view this as a climate emergency. If we continue to allow the liquid natural gas units to be built around Europe to facilitate American frack gas, then we are not serious about it. We already have one such unit in Ireland. We need to change the system, not the climate.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός (NI).
text: Madam President, according to studies carried out, global temperatures have risen by 1% in the last 140 years. Also, according to a 1998 UN survey, in 2009 Manhattan should not have been on the surface of the earth, but should have sunk. I say this because it shows the climate of terror that prevails and is linked to this new fairy tale that you are selling us, "the fairy tale of climate change". Of course there is climate change, but it is part of the change that has existed on earth for millions of years. And here I want to stress the oxymoron and the joke of the case, that we see people, who are shouting about climate change, being the ones who have luxury cars at their disposal, travelling from side to side in the world on planes and they don't give a about what's going on in general. But they are the ones who want to blame the average citizen and essentially make him self-scourge, because he dares to open the air condition in his house so that it is hot in winter. These are unacceptable things. Should we see, first of all, what do those who talk about climate change do about all this? They cannot be in the comfort of the European Parliament and their own home, having a good time and talking to us about climate change, for which they are by force trying to convince us. And I cannot accept as a position what they claim. Because we have reached a society in which what is said about climate change cannot be questioned. So stop this terrorism, because I slowly see that climate change is the new fairy tale that they are telling us to tyrannize us for the rest of our lives.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I do not share the view that this resolution, which we are going to vote on this week, has no teeth. I would therefore like to highlight three priorities. Firstly, the fight against the deforestation of rainforests. Every two minutes an area of 35 football pitches is lost due to the deforestation of the forests. The world's forests make a significant contribution to mitigating climate change by absorbing greenhouse gas emissions. For the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, therefore, the protection of our forests is at the heart of climate action. We have included a whole chapter in the resolution on this subject. Another priority for us is the compatibility of climate action and the protection of jobs. If we want to convince our international partners, we must show them that climate protection is possible without the need to destroy jobs. In the EU, we have managed to reduce CO2 emissions by 23%, while gross national product has increased by 23% over the same period. But to do this, investment in programmes for a fair transition is essential. Luxembourg has set a good example and has announced that it will double its contributions to the United Nations Green Climate Fund. I hope that as many colleagues as possible will follow suit. Air and sea transport is a third point that must definitely be installed and for which ambitious objectives must be set.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the news of the seriousness of the situation in which we find ourselves accumulates. Today we are again warned by the World Meteorological Organization, seeing a new record of greenhouse gas emissions. We are already suffering the consequences of climate change. That is why citizens would not endure another empty debate on the climate emergency if we did not take action, proposals and actions. At the next COP in Madrid, Parliament will defend a position consistent with the Paris Agreement. A COP that we remember pre-first review of national contributions, which is now insufficient. So much so that they lead to an increase in temperature, with catastrophic consequences.  Unfortunately, in Europe we have not done our homework either and, due to the lack of agreement of the Member States, the European Union is approaching this COP with an insufficient emission reduction target by 2030, which has not yet been updated and without reaching consensus on the 2050 climate neutrality target.  If Europeans want to lead the ecological transition, we must move from words to facts, passing a climate law and the Green New Deal, ensuring a fair ecological transition. We must put policies in place so that no one is left behind in this transition. There are regions, sectors and citizens who will need greater support to achieve the benefits associated with this transition. This is our obligation: to guarantee your future.

name: Catherine Chabaud (Renew).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from my sporting past, I have learned the power of collective action, especially in the face of major challenges. In the face of this extraordinary challenge posed by climate change, our strength will be to be able to play together. What citizens expect is the leadership of a Europe that joins forces to implement solutions. The ambition of the Green Pact, the EIB's first steps towards a European climate bank, the conclusions of the Council on the ocean last week and this resolution are proof that we can converge our ideas to meet this challenge, beyond our differences. I am particularly pleased that in this resolution we have been able to underline the consequences of the ocean and, at the same time, the fundamental role it plays in the balance of the climate. The ocean is also part of the solution, and this will be one of the topics of the Blue COP since, next week, the Chilean president will launch a platform of "Ocean" solutions, namely, the restoration of marine and coastal ecosystems, the development of marine renewable energies or the design of green boats. In conclusion, I repeat and repeat that Europe, which is the world's leading maritime area, must build a real maritime strategy in the Green Blue Deal.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are running out of time, but we are already missing it. Wildfires and floods are on the rise; Venice is underwater; Biodiversity is collapsing; resources are scarce. All the lights are red! It is this cry of alarm that citizens and scientists are sending out. Faced with this observation, the time is not for political slogans, meaningless communication or demagoguery. In the face of this, the European Parliament must take responsibility. It is our duty to declare a state of ecological and climate emergency. What does that mean? That is not to say that you have to plant three wind turbines on a coal-fired power plant or electrify buses that bring thousands of passengers to fly. The system should not be changed, but it must be changed profoundly. Concretely, ladies and gentlemen, have the courage to put in place a new CAP, make sure that a kerosene tax is introduced. What are we waiting for to stop all unnecessary projects? Not a euro in fossil fuels. Are we going to wake up? Let's sweep in front of our door! Here, from our one seat, we emit 19,000 tonnes of CO2 every year. Let's be reasonable! So I am telling you very simply that the ball is in your court: either we let governments do nothing, or we make sure that this Parliament takes over Europe to become the climate leader and takes action. I say to you: on Thursday, let us be proud to vote together on the resolution on the ecological emergency and the climate emergency. (The speaker refuses a question blue card from Robert Rowland)

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the policies that Europe has already put in place to reduce greenhouse gases and protect the environment outline very ambitious commitments to the EU's climate neutrality. These commitments, however, raise serious questions for our companies as to whether they can remain competitive globally, despite the new costs generated by environmental targets to be achieved in a short time, and to the Member States, if they can fully support energy demand, their energy independence and at what cost. However, at a time when this House is demanding heavy sacrifices from states, citizens and businesses, it is the European Parliament that is the first to set a bad example: how much CO2 and how much money is constantly being wasted on maintaining both the Brussels and Strasbourg seats? Think of the economic costs of over EUR 200 million per year and the periodic movements of thousands of people, vehicles and materials and their emissions. Nothing but climate neutrality! We claim to be green only when it is up to others to pay, while we make merchant ears. How do we think we are really credible in the eyes of the world?

name: Anna Zalewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The Minister, the Finnish Minister, and the Representative of the Commission rightly repeat the words: common sense, justice.  Yes, this is necessary because we must carry out the whole transformation in harmony with our citizens. Yellow vests in France, protests by farmers in the Netherlands, Germans who have received information about huge increases in electricity prices, rampant garbage prices are not conducive to discussing the need for even deeper analysis or changes in their surroundings. This is important. However, this solidarity and reason does not resonate in the resolution. We are going with nothing, because every second paragraph of this resolution is simply an exclusive paragraph. We are not serious. We only throw declarations, passwords, and do not answer questions "how". How can we go, proudly present our position in Madrid, since we do not know how we will construct a green deal. How much money will we spend on this? Finally, the bill announced by Frans Timmermans over the well, new green governance laws. We have not yet implemented the Paris Agreement, the Katowice Agreement. You really need ambition, but also responsibility.

name: Nikolaj Villumsen (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President! I was having breakfast this morning with my fourteen-month-old daughter, and then I thought about this debate about climate change. The reality is that if we do not act, the children who are now playing in the playground will grow up in a completely changed world with devastating storms, floods, droughts, famine and millions of climate refugees. We owe it to future generations to act. The good news is that we can achieve it if we act in time. The EU will fail to abandon the Paris Agreement if we only reduce CO2 emissions by 55% by 2030. We need to reach 70% to get to the finish line. Ladies and gentlemen, think of the future when you vote! Ladies and gentlemen, vote for the necessary action on climate change now!

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Madam President, the EU likes to see itself as an ambitious front—runner on the agenda of climate change, and indeed we are great at setting targets for the very distant future. But, last week, I was a member of an ACP delegation to Rwanda, and I listened to the EU’s partners from the Pacific and the Caribbean region. All these countries were basically already stating that they live the reality of a climate catastrophe and a climate emergency. What we are only talking about here now is already reality there, and they are fed up with our talking and our extremely long—distance targets and the declarations that we are making.  Action must be taken, and one of the first steps that we should take – and what the European Union should be doing – is to get its partners, the greatest economies of this world, back on board and get them to take on the responsibilities that they agreed to when they signed the Paris Agreement. The EU cannot be left alone with that. It has to bring back the United States. It has to bring the G20 countries back on board and remind them of their responsibilities. I think this will be a great task for Josep Borrel, as High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to get back the partners – the greatest economies in the world – to join us in delivering on the targets of the Paris Agreement.

name: Hildegard Bentele (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The next World Climate Conference coincides with the start of work by the new Commission. In other words, we have a particularly good opportunity to take a stand and to give concrete to our politically formulated objective of doubling climate-relevant measures in development cooperation. We need better access to renewable energy and support for investment in climate technologies and knowledge sharing. We need to build sustainable supply chains and further develop the circular economy. We need international partnerships in the sustainable use of forests, land, water and resources, for example through certification systems, and we need to invest in civil protection and early warning systems. Last but not least, in view of the increasing exodus from the countryside worldwide, it is becoming increasingly important that we rebuild our cities more efficiently and in a more climate-friendly way, or that new settlements or new cities are built in a completely different way. With this resolution, we MEPs are on the way to the 26th climate conference. I am particularly keen to see what contribution the new Commissioner for Development, Mrs Urpilainen, will make to this.

name: Delara Burkhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The people of Venice have noticed in recent weeks that the climate emergency is not an abstract but also a brutal reality here in Europe. Flooding has flooded 80% of the city and caused millions of dollars in damage. These events show once again that it must not be allowed to remain mere lip service. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs is now presenting this House with a resolution for COP 25, which, on the one hand, is a clear commitment to constructive leadership. On the other hand, however, it is also an appeal to the EU institutions and Member States for more ambitions in European climate policy, above all for strengthening the social dimension. For example, the EU is to raise its emission reduction target to 55% by 2030 and become climate neutral by 2050 at the latest – all within the framework of a just transition: a fund for socially just structural change or even the fight against energy poverty. As S&D, we stand for a climate policy that cares not only for those who are afraid of the end of the world, but also for those who are afraid of the end of the month. Putting the brakes on today is against the interests of these people. I am particularly pleased that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European People's Committee has called for an end to nuclear energy. Let us not leave future generations alone with nuclear waste. The energy of the future must be safe, renewable, emission-free and radiation-free. That is why paragraph 56 must remain in the version it now has.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your work during these years and also thank Spain for hosting and allowing this important COP 25 meeting to be held on the scheduled date in Madrid. COP 25 must establish a new level of ambition both to advance the Paris agreements and for signatory States to address in the national plans to be presented by 2020 by a greater commitment of all sectors, economic, industrial and productive. We are facing an unprecedented climate and ecological urgency. That is why, at COP 25 in Madrid and in the next COP 15 we need greater leadership from Europe. Greater leadership to reduce our emissions and to restore the ecological boundaries of the planet. Getting Europe the world's first economy by 2050 with neutral emissions is a commitment that all Member States must support. Scientists tell us there's still time, but the reality is that there's less and less.

name: Aileen McLeod (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, coming from Scotland, which has already declared a climate emergency, I support calls for this Parliament to declare a climate and environmental emergency in Europe.  But in doing so, it is absolutely essential that we commit to taking bolder and urgent climate action in response to the deteriorating situation. We must send a strong message to our citizens and to the rest of the world that Europe will lead and will implement effective policies and actions to meet the 1.5°C target. I would urge the Commission to ensure that its plans for a new European climate law and a green deal recognise the urgency and scale of the climate emergency that we face, and have at their heart the well—being of people and planet, because we must also ensure that the transition to net zero is just and fair and leaves no one behind. We need all countries across the EU and beyond to step up to the plate and to come to Glasgow next year with serious climate commitments. (The speaker declined to answer a blue-card question from Mr Rowland)

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find the umpteenth debate on the climate emergency frankly cloying and on the edge of futility. For you, however, immigration is not an emergency, work is not an emergency, trade relations with other countries are not an emergency, business crises are not an emergency. The emergency dictates the fashion of the moment and therefore, in short, with Greta actually giving the agenda to this European Parliament. Among other things, this propaganda risks fuelling a dangerous intergenerational confrontation. The President of the Commission now seems to be a fundamentalist on the environment. You've gone so far as to deny what scientists say that don't respect the line you have. In short, I would generally like a Parliament that starts to deal with the real problems and also a little more realistic and concrete.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, you are methodically cultivating the dangerous notion of individual responsibility. So is it the fault of the worker who has moved by car or plane and is loading it with green taxes, or is it the large aviation groups and car manufacturers in the European Union, which the European Union and governments subsidise with green funds? But the truth is stubborn: ninety large groups have accounted for two-thirds of global exhaust emissions since 1988 and twenty monopolies for 35% of carbon emissions in recent decades. Exon Mobil, BP, Shell, Total and others advertise their green projects, and are some of the biggest polluters. Wars over group competitions have incalculable consequences. Environmental protection presupposes a centrally designed economy, free from the criterion of profit, without exploitation, without imperialist wars and monopolies, with the aim of meeting modern social needs, with full activation of technological and scientific progress for the safety and health of the population and for the protection of the environment.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, climate change is an extremely serious challenge and this challenge must be dealt with very seriously. Populist speeches, in my opinion, do not bring any solution.  I believe that we must deal very seriously, take very strong and hasty measures, but these measures must be based on impact studies, both in terms of the effect on the climate, but also the effect on jobs and European competitiveness, European industry. I believe that we must at the same time make every effort to make these efforts global, and not only in the European Union, because otherwise the effect will not be the one we want and at the same time we will lose a lot of competitiveness, so all based on impact studies, based on scientific research and effects in all areas.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We only have ten years to go until we are to achieve the UN's global sustainability goals, and we will certainly not meet the targets if we do not take the climate issue seriously. And in doing so, the Paris Agreement is central – everything is connected. The climate issue is the fate of our time. It is about the common future of all of us. The right-wing extremists in here speak in a way that we have a choice, as if the climate crisis does not exist. The fact is that the climate crisis is here and that the transition must of course take place with the equality glasses on.  Therefore, from the International Committee on Development and Development, where I am sitting, we want to press for a truly ambitious policy within the European Union while taking responsibility globally. Climate change threatens to reverse the progress achieved in the fields of global development, health, poverty reduction and conflict prevention.  That is why my message to the EU Member States is that we must take on the leader's jersey, both at home and globally. Among other things, we see that the old commitment to mobilise USD 100 billion a year globally to support developing countries will no longer be enough, because we are already lagging behind. It is time to move from words to action.

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we are facing a climate emergency of unprecedented scale. Today, the World Meteorological Organization said that there is no sign of slowdown – let alone decline – in emissions. They also said that the gap between targets and reality is glaring and growing. It is not enough to speak of climate emergency today; now it’s time to speak about climate action. That applies to this Parliament, and it applies to Europe as well. We, in Europe, are not doing nearly enough. Our own targets are not enough, and we are still putting billions every year into subsidising the use of fossil fuels. Just think of that: we are subsidising something that is the cause of our emergency. It’s like throwing oil into the flames. Our own emission reduction targets have to be increased; we have to protect our own biodiversity; and we have to move towards 100% renewables within Europe. That is the message we have to take to Madrid: that we show that we live by our words. Then we can demand more from the others as well. The Commission has to do that in the next five years, and the Member States also have to follow suit.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my first words are of recognition, and I recall, for our friend and colleague Paco Gambús, who was a Member in the last parliamentary term and was now an adviser to our delegation and passed away this Friday, at the age of 45. Paco, from heaven you will continue to give us your strength to continue defending this great project that is Europe. Thank you, Paco. The EU has led the previous conferences with Commissioner Arias Cañete. I would like to congratulate you on your great work, for your rationality and negotiating capacity, because they have been necessary for the Paris Agreement, to protect our planet, but also to maintain competitiveness and economic development in Europe.  We need to move forward, of course; with more ambitious goals, of course. But first we must strengthen the consensuses, the Paris compliances and the coordination between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, because this will combine the fight against climate change, the economy and competitiveness.  But we must also invest efforts in those countries that are major emitters, and they must be ambitious. Because only together will we be able to save the planet; because climate and health don't understand borders, and in Madrid we have a great opportunity.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, my colleague, you have given us news which makes us extremely sad. I remember with great affection Mr Gambús – Paco – a colleague with whom I personally worked, with whom so many of us have worked, very profitably, an extremely serious, committed and truly exquisite person. I can only express my condolences to his family, friends and those who are mourning him. We will miss all of us very much, so first of all thank you for remembering it.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the truth is that the planet is giving us a historical lesson as a species. It is that we have been subjecting it to a suffering since the nineteenth century and the planet can no longer. He's planted up. And he told us that we either change or disappear. We have a chance. We have it if we change and adapt and move towards a carbon-neutral economy. That is the debate we are going to have at the Madrid summit. We're going to seize this opportunity. And please, let's stop sterile debates like the one we're having between different groups: that if gravity, that if you emergency. Decisions have to be made. With a lot of determination. Immediate, ambitious, concrete decisions. And look, if we're going towards a ⸻ we're ⸻, it has to be from justice. And justice involves environmental taxation, not only the income criterion, but the pollution criterion. It means a global fund for the right transition. It ⸻ what a colleague has said now⸻ to recover the funding of one hundred billion dollars for developing countries and that they can make the reforms. It means deforestation-free supply chains in Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, we can take this opportunity, because it's too late. The planet in historical terms is telling us that it no longer supports us as a dominant species with a carbon-based economy. Either we change and we adapt or we just disappear. Choose. (He refused to have Robert Rowland ask him a question under the "blue card" procedure.)

name: Andreas Glück (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Climate change is probably the greatest challenge of our time – for me as a politician, but also for me personally, because I want to do justice to my two children for the future. It is a challenge, on the one hand, to respond to climate protection, but also to not lose sight of jobs in Europe. I do not want to use words to raise alarm, on the contrary: it is a question of encouraging, motivating, so that the best technological possibilities from Europe can be used. Fear paralyzes, but inspires courage. We do not want to be afraid, but courage. And we must be judged by our actions, not by our words. And we need to act urgently. That is why I personally consider the term 'urgency' to be much better than 'emergency', because as a specialist in surgery, I hear something different from what we, as politicians, need to do right now. We need to create framework conditions for the best technology to be used, but we have to stay out when it comes to assessing individual discussions. European CO2 allowance trading is important in this regard. We need to strengthen this, to extend it to other sectors, so that we can play a role in the world.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to begin my speech with an excited memory for my friend Paco Gambús who, in addition to being a great parliamentarian and a great person, was a person very committed to the environment, who did an excellent job in the Committee on the Environment when he was a parliamentarian in this house. And I want to vindicate him as what he was: a great mp and a better person. Having said that, I would also like to refer to the next COP.  I am afraid that we will go on Thursday to declare the climate emergency here in the European Parliament - which will be excellent news - but that we will go back to the COP empty-handed. Without the 2050 objective of determined carbon neutrality, with an intermediate objective still faltering and with many reforms to be done: withdrawing coal subsidies, reforming the CAP to align it with Paris, letting the European Central Bank continue to buy coal-linked assets – many things that remain to be done. Therefore, on Thursday we declare the climate emergency is great news, but now it is our turn to go to action to respond to all those young people who from the streets are asking us to take this issue seriously.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, science demands decisive political responses in the fight against climate change. In Europe, it is important to increase our ambition to reduce greenhouse gas emissions while preserving our way of life in the best possible way. It is imperative to be ambitious, but it is no less important to honour our commitments. To do this, we need a new pact for technology, a pact that will lead to faster implementation of technologies that can make a difference. This is a challenge that is not impossible. However, we cannot face it alone. In Madrid, at COP25, we must be clear when we come across the other delegations. We are prepared to continue to lead global climate action, but we need firm commitments from around the world. I urge the Council and the Commission to bring us a reflection on how to achieve this ambitious global commitment at COP25.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Mr President, climate emergency is here, whether we like it or not. And it is time for this Parliament, but also for other parliaments in Europe and around the world, to take note of this. It's a result of scientists telling us for over thirty years that we have a problem, but we pretended it wasn't such a big problem. We now face the challenge of our generation. A challenge that can be compared last time to the Second World War, or to the fight against other totalitarian regimes. However, I think that this is also a huge opportunity. An opportunity for us, similar to the conquest of the moon. We really need to take a positive approach to this and try to make sure that we can change our economy, both in Europe and around the world, not only ecologically, but also fairly. Because otherwise we'll lose people's trust. Ecological justice is something that must happen in our efforts to save the climate. Because that's the only way future generations will give us confidence.

name: Damien Carême (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I have one minute to speak. In one minute, 95,129 m2 of forests disappear worldwide, 416,666 tons of ice melt in the Arctic, three marine animals die because of plastic dumped into the oceans. Five years is the time that all experts give us to reverse the trend, to ensure that life continues on our magnificent planet Earth and thus give hope and a horizon to current and future generations. So let us declare a climate and environmental emergency, but we must not - as Mr Canfin said earlier - that it is just a symbol. The young people he mentioned make fun of the symbols. Time is no longer for symbols but for action. Concrete, ambitious and immediate climate action is needed. We need to review all our European policies in the face of the Paris Agreement and only through this prism. Five years is the length of our mandate, ladies and gentlemen. In five years, we can take extreme pride in taking on our responsibilities and thus securing a future for our children, grandchildren and their descendants. Otherwise, in five years' time, we will feel a deep shame that we have not had the courage and audacity to continue to look our families in the eye. I beg you: let us vote on the climate and environmental emergency, but let us commit ourselves by action.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Many thanks to the Commissioner for the good cooperation over the last five years, especially as far as I am concerned. At LULUCF, we have made concrete climate policy. I believe that this makes much more sense than talking about symbolic politics, while one side of Parliament denies climate change and the other then has symbolic debates on the proclamation of a European climate emergency. No, let us talk about specific issues, about concrete measures. Let us talk about what.B, for example, agriculture and forestry can do, how it can bind more carbon, how we can deal with climate change with more humus, than we do with such symbolic debates that will not take us any further.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Mr President, a few days ago, Oxford Dictionary announced the word of the year – it was ‘climate emergency’, and it reflects our reality. All around the world, young people are on the streets telling us – politicians – to take real, meaningful action to avoid a climate emergency. We often feel that they are the only adults in a room; that they are the only ones to show real leadership. Let me ask you, what kind of leaders are we if we fail to listen, and if we are stuck miles behind those people we are supposed to represent? With this resolution, we can send a clear message to these youngsters; a simple one: ‘we hear you, and we are here to act’. Voting against the resolution is a different message. It’s the message of more business as usual. More procrastination. More inaction. That we are not willing to listen, neither to people nor to science. Let’s vote for this resolution, declare climate emergency in Europe and show to the world that the European Union is the global leader in climate action and that this House is ready to treat the situation with the gravity it deserves, so that our citizens have the future they deserve.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I agree that it is very important to send this signal and declare an emergency. However, I do not believe that this is enough – and I have to agree with Mr Lins for once – but that concrete measures are also needed. That is why, Mr Lins, I will be watching to see whether you vote in favour of our Green resolution on Thursday, in which we list the very measures that are needed now. Thank you for pointing it out. The good news is that renewable energies have become so cheap that we in the European Union would be downright stupid if we continued to chain ourselves to fossil fuels. For renewable energies require investment, while fossil fuels will simply continue to incur costs. And I'm not even talking about environmental costs, I'm just talking about operating costs. There is a reason why, for example, in India, the coal-fired power stations that were supposed to be under construction are now being taken out of line and are not being built. There is a reason why China is planning so much less fossil energy in its next five-year plan. Let's not miss this opportunity! But we really have to say what this situation is: it is an emergency situation. I would therefore ask you to vote in favour of our resolution. (The speaker declined to answer a question about the procedure for Robert Andrew Rowland's 'blue card')

name: Jessica Polfjärd (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The climate challenge is serious, it is here and now and requires political determination, not panic. Because if we politicians panic, who's going to stand for sane and balance. Instead, we should contribute courage and hope to the debate. We must invest in the measures that are most effective and that reduce emissions the most. That is why industry and the transport sector need to be able to switch to clean energy. And therefore, it is not time to waste time condemning certain fossil-free energy types because of ideology. That is why we must also be able to count on nuclear power in order to achieve our climate ambitions, to accelerate electrification and to phase out coal power.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir (Renew).
text: Mr President, on 13 November, The Lancet published the article entitled 'Countdown, Health and Climate Change: Ensuring that the health of the child born today will not be determined by climate change'. It's the largest international scientific journal that says it. It is indeed our health and that of our children that is at stake. Climate change is an emergency, a health emergency, an absolute health emergency. Already today, people in Africa are suffering and dying from the health consequences of global warming. We owe it to ourselves to reach out to them. Tomorrow, the health emergency will be in the regions of Europe, already threatened by the proliferation of new infectious diseases linked to warming. Emergency does not mean panic, however. The emergency department is the one where crisis management is anticipated and organized, far from the catastrophism and manipulation of populations through fear. We must quickly and serenely organize this emergency.
