name: Barbara Thaler (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which At the beginning of our discussion here in the room, I heard the words clarity, understanding and transparency today. I believe that yes, we need clarity through careful choice of words in this debate, and we need transparency through sound figures. I welcome the discussions surrounding COP 25. I believe that I speak for the vast majority here that we Europeans have accepted the preservation of our earth not only for ourselves, but for all and for our children, as one of our main tasks. That is a good thing. Our shoulders are strong, and I believe that those who can wear more have a moral obligation to wear more. That is what we can do as Europe. I believe it is our great strength that we can overcome complex problems with technological solutions. But we can achieve far too little on our own. For me, sustainability is not an either-or question, but the interplay of environmental protection and the economy, environmental protection and mobility and so on and so forth. The power is in balance.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Mr President! The planet's temperature is higher than ever in recent years. By 2030, climate change will add an additional 100 million people to poverty, and by 2050 the use of the field will be 5 to 30 percent lower. In addition to the increasing aeration of ailing areas and the melting of glaciers, climate change has a direct impact on the social and environmental situation in which we find ourselves. It is high time that, more specifically, more harshly, if you will, we face these changes, but at the same time we should also pay particular attention to the fact that the transition to purely renewable sourcing does not affect European competitiveness and population. The resolution we are debating today sends out a strong political message from the Union before the start of the United Nations climate meeting in Madrid. I welcome this and would like the international community to support such an ambitious project, because our actions directly affect our lives and the lives of all future generations.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the cultural battle linked to the great objective of environmental sustainability is a fair battle and must be conducted intelligently and rigorously, but above all realistically. Shouting at the climate emergency in general can make sense to some. It is more correct for me to talk about urgency, not emergency, but what interests me most in this place is that if there is one area where this battle has been dealt with intelligently, and Europe has won. Then European entrepreneurs must not be burdened with an additional cost to achieving a goal that they are already guaranteeing. On the contrary, let us look at the good practices of our industries and businesses, because from there we can draw an example to remove the abstractness of certain debates that we see here in this Parliament. We imitate our businesses to ensure true sustainability.

name: Adam Jarubas (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Climate change is a great challenge for the whole planet, not just the European Union. It is said that the planet and the environment are only rented from future generations. At stake is the fate of our children and grandchildren. We must be ambitious, but our ambition must be preceded by a thorough analysis of the economic and social impact of our actions. If it turns out that our actions are weakening the European economy, then the world will not follow us, so we will not achieve the global climate targets. We have a climate marathon ahead of us, not a sprint. Our actions must stimulate new technologies and jobs. On the road to a low- and zero-emission economy, we must be accompanied by an ambitious Just Transition Fund supporting the most vulnerable regions, for which the transformation will be the greatest social and economic challenge, and at the same time those regions that cannot in themselves generate the necessary resources or rely on sufficient support from the national level. Five billion euros in the Multiannual Financial Framework for the Just Transition Fund is a good start, but over the next ten years, these funds must be several times greater if we want to achieve what we are debating today if we want to be serious and effective.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We are all working together to address the challenges of climate change. It is therefore very important that we act in a coordinated and judicious way. When it comes to climate change, remember not only the emergency, but also its potential. I am convinced that the European Union can only become climate neutral if it makes the most of its knowledge. I would like to point out that thorough impact assessments are needed so that the economic and climate goals are not contradictory but encouraging each other. Instead of words, let us demonstrate by action that the European Union can be the first to address the challenges of climate change. By declaring a climate emergency, I believe that we are stimulating decision-makers to rush, and what is most needed now is wisdom and prudence, because if we act badly, we may be going in the opposite direction as we planned.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are responsible for our globe. Europe is absolutely in line with the Paris targets with emissions trading, energy saving targets, with expansion targets for renewable energies, already on the basis of 40% CO2. Yes, we can and we need to do more. We want to be a global role model. But we have to take people and businesses with us. But what some of the left and the Greens have announced here today is unfortunately not a takeaway, it is frightening with disaster scenarios, threatening with the most extreme forecasts for sea level rise. You are talking about a state of emergency.  A famine justifies a state of emergency, a civil war, a devastating earthquake. Declaring a state of emergency always means the repeal of the regular legislation. Anyone who declares a state of emergency no longer wants to argue, wants to frighten and intimidate, and jobs and social dislocations do not matter, and democracy and the rule of law do not matter. That is why I am in favour of taking the climate targets more seriously. However, the declaration of a state of emergency does not justify the situation. If you declare a state of emergency, we declare a state of emergency for the industry.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Mr President, we are facing an unprecedented crisis that arouses legitimate emotion. But the job of politics is to respond to emotion through reason. However, I am concerned that we often respond to emotion with a form of unreason. This is the case in some of the texts proposed to us on the climate crisis. Let us pause for a moment on the issue of energy, especially nuclear energy, which we are being asked to forcefully condemn as an energy that does not help to respond to climate problems. However, it is very clear, ladies and gentlemen, that if we are to deal with the situation we are in today, we must- even explain the IPCC- to accommodate all the available resources that do not produce carbon, and nuclear is one of them. Of course, in the long run, the security issues raised by this energy pose huge problems. But today, it would be crazy to dig our own grave by organizing the deconstruction of a sector that can help us to meet, in the immediate future, the climate challenge that awaits us. Finally, we must also use, with our intelligence, this single market that we have built to make the fight for climate rebalancing prevail. That, in my view, is the sense of the work that we have to do on the economic front and that is also waiting for us to meet the ecological challenge.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm cúpla abairt a rá ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo, ós rud é go raibh mé i mo thoscaire i bPáras, in Katowice agus in Marrakech ag na cruinnithe COP sin. Firstly, great credit is due to the Juncker Commission – and especially Commissioner Arias Cañete – on giving leadership in Paris and bringing the Clean Energy Package through the last Parliament. Now we have to implement it. One point that I think needs to be made very strongly is that it is fine to talk about ambition in the future, but what we need now – especially from the Member States – is action. What are they going to do this year, next year, and the year after? Not 2030, not 2040, not 2050. Secondly, the Council pointed out, rightly, that no one should be left behind. I would add to that ‘through no fault of their own’. People who work in peat factories and energy stations in my constituency, or in coal in Poland, need to be helped, and a just transition fund is vital to be part of this. Finally, I just want to say to Commissioner Timmermans that he’ll have to ensure that ambition is matched with inclusivity, and that global leadership will have to be practical. Everybody has a part to play.

name: Radan Kanev (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we are all concerned and we are all committed to an ambitious policy: to a ‘new green deal’. But what exactly is this policy? What exactly does ‘new green deal’ mean? Using this term we must go back in history and we must recall the real significance of the term. Was it a list of prohibitions? Was it a list of limitations? Was it a list of taxes affecting those who already suffer the most? No. It was a large- scale public and private investment programme aiming at ambitious development, innovation, new infrastructure, new businesses, new models of growth, new jobs. And our new green deal in Europe shall be a deal for growth and jobs, for new opportunities, for the regions in transition, for new hope for those affected, for a new clean technology, for science, for innovation, for investment in precisely the regions most dependent on fossils and suffering most from the present crisis.

name: Ljudmila Novak (PPE).
text: – Mr President! Climate change is certainly an extremely important topic, although it is still not a disaster, but it can, of course, occur if we do not take concrete action. It is right that we discuss this, and it is even more important that we take concrete measures. And, of course, I am counting on this, and I expect the new European Commission to actually propose concrete amendments. I also support increasing resources for these purposes, because only with new technologies, with a new way of working and using energy, will we be able to reduce emissions, because I do not believe that we are prepared to change our way of life so much that this could also significantly help to reduce energy consumption. I ask the Commission, to what extent are these climate objectives taken into account when we conclude trade agreements with countries outside the European Union?

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, of course most of us are committed to the objectives of combating climate change. Several Member States have already signed up, including Slovakia, where I come from. However, in order to achieve these objectives, especially with regard to achieving greenhouse neutrality by 2050, we must have some flexibility in using the instruments by which we achieve this objective. We must respect the possibility for each country to choose its energy mix, and I think, and many of us think, that gas must be part of it, at least from that medium-term perspective, and also the core. The core is, of course, one of the sources that does not emit any emissions, but of course we can ask about safety and sustainability. I therefore disagree and would appeal to you to amend an article or paragraph that talks about the core as an economically and environmentally unsustainable instrument and an energy source.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Mr President, declaring an emergency, catastrophe or crisis without actually having policies in place that will actually have a meaningful impact on the environment and on climate change will simply be just denying the reality that is there at the moment. I think, if the European Union to be serious about climate change, it has to make sure that all policies are inclusive: that not only do they send out a strong message, but that people actually buy in and support what needs to be done to change how we live, how we work, and how we commute. If we don’t, we will simply end up continually talking about it as if the discussion itself will have an outcome. We have to be honest with ourselves: we need policies now – not next year or in five years’ time. We need to be imaginative and creative. The bottom line here is that unless you have access to finance; unless companies and businesses invest in research and innovation; unless our colleges have the capacity to research and innovate in the areas of climate change, then we really will be talking about a catastrophe and a crisis, because it will be just that. We need to act now with inclusive, imaginative policies, allowing industry to adapt to address the issues.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we need measures that question an unsustainable system in its essence and not measures to ensure the survival of this system in a more green version. To private energy monopolies, we must counter public control of the energy sector, if what we want is the sustainable functioning of it, which consums social and environmental concerns. To the paradigm of individual car transport, we must counter modern, efficient, quality and progressively free public transport systems. To the carbon business, from buying and selling permits to pollute, we must counter a normative approach to reducing greenhouse gases. To the unsustainable models of production and consumption, we must counter the fight against consumerism and the waste associated with it. Encouraging local production and consumption, short supply chains, a vision of international trade more based on complementarity than competition - this is what we need if we want to go beyond the inconsequential shredding of summit concerns at summit.  Capitalism is not and will not be green.

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Mr President, there’s no climate emergency in this place – just a lot of hot air. If you were serious, you would show real leadership by stopping the senseless pollution caused by transporting this Parliament between Brussels and Strasbourg 12 times a year. By 2050, the environmental impact of this will be 600 000 tonnes of CO2 emissions.  Nearly every candidate for the EU presidency – including Mr Timmermans – agreed on the stupidity of two parliaments. Only Mr Macron clings on to the vanity of Strasbourg. When will this Parliament end such hypocrisy over the environment? Speaker after speaker says that the lives of our children, our planet and our existence are at risk, but we’re not prepared to end our own pollution by stopping this stupid twin—Parliament structure of Strasbourg and Brussels. Try explaining that to your grandchildren.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Mr President! We see climate change every day, the consequences of theirs, when we watch floods, fires, either in Venice or in Slovenian Izola, Piran. It is easy to declare a climate state of emergency, but we need to do much more. We need to find new technologies, new opportunities for entrepreneurship, opportunities for science, we also need to provide funding for this in budgets. We have a duty to explain to people the measures that follow. What are we going to do in the field of energy? How do we provide low-carbon energy? With renewables, it is certainly also with nuclear energy. What are we going to do in agriculture? What we are going to do in transport is make people aware and that they will be part of those changes that they will support. What is also, or more important, is that this role, which the European Union plays at home, be transferred around the world and that we also convince the biggest economies: the US, China and India.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, climate change is the single most important issue today. As a member of the ACP—EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I’m in regular dialogue with parliamentarians representing vulnerable communities. Nearly one—third of all citizens in Small Island Developing States (SIDS) live just a few metres above sea level. For them, the existential threat of climate change is already here: storm surges, saltwater intrusion and coastal destruction have resulted in failing crops, water shortages and an uncertain future – contributing, in turn, to migration. Meanwhile, areas of the UK such as Cumbria in 2015 and Yorkshire just a few weeks ago, are experiencing unprecedented floods, leaving thousands of people homeless and destroying businesses. Governments have spent years ignoring all the scientific warnings. Now our young people are taking action, and I applaud them for their efforts. I was proud to sign the Green New Deal pledge and join millions of people all over the world in the global climate strike. We have one home. We share it, and we must protect it.

name: Mauri Pekkarinen (Renew).
text: – (start of speech without microphone) ... 23% reduction in emissions within the European Union over eight years. Over the next ten years, we must succeed in reducing them by 33%. It's a tough, brave mission, but you have to commit to it. And that can be achieved, and it does not require any incitement and construction of hysteria. I therefore do not believe that any climate emergency should be declared either. Action and strong commitments are needed. I believe that Finland is a good example of how to achieve a lot of hysteria – not hysteria, but strong, hard action. We have decided to stop using coal by 2030. We have decided that Finland will be a carbon neutral country already in 2035. It is my hope that we here will decide on joint commitments. Each country itself takes responsibility for their implementation, and in that way – in a confidence-building way – we will achieve this goal.

name: Robert Rowland (NI).
text: – Mr President, I’ve had about nine or ten blue—card attempts rejected, so I get slightly more than one minute, I hope. What we’re seeing here, in this climate change debate, is all rationality disappearing and climate alarmism basically becoming a belief system: it’s moving out of the scientific realm into a more humanistic or religious realm.  The key points of climate change are the following. Firstly, you’re undergoing an enormous deindustrialisation plan, of which the UK alone has estimated the cost as GBP 1 trillion. To undergo a similar—scale operation for Europe is going to cost trillions and trillions of euros. Secondly, the actual product itself that you’re replacing the hydrocarbons with – either solar or wind – is intermittent and requires huge taxpayer subsidies. In the UK alone, again, it’s over GBP 11 billion a year. The third point is that you’re losing tax revenue from hydrocarbons, which in the UK is GBP 40 billion a year, and replacing it with a subsidy. So I ask all the people in here: how on earth are you going to fund all the precious public services when you are subsidising renewables?

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: miembro de la Comisión. – Señor presidente, como ya han hecho a lo largo de este debate diversos miembros de la Cámara y la propia presidencia, yo también quería dedicar un emocionado recuerdo a Francisco Gambús, que fue un gran parlamentario europeo, una persona forjadora de consensos y un hombre plenamente comprometido con el desarrollo de las políticas medioambientales y climáticas de la Unión Europea. Y quisiera trasladar nuestro dolor y pesar por su pérdida a su familia. I would also like to thank Members for their continued commitment to ambitious global climate action, thereby providing additional political momentum ahead of another important COP. I have listened carefully to the debate today, and I am encouraged by the engagement of the Members of this House. I appreciate your commitment to maintaining the European Union’s role as a leader in the field of international climate action.  A strong and united European Union message will be instrumental to continuing to deliver on our leadership during COP25 in Madrid and beyond. I am convinced that the European Commission and the European Council, under the leadership of the Finnish Presidency, will contribute to the conclusion of the negotiations on Article 6 of the Paris Agreement so as to strengthen international cooperation to reduce emissions globally. After Madrid, our work must continue, both domestically and internationally. With our domestic experience and external policy instruments and dialogues, we are in a position to help our partners to advance their transition to a low-carbon, climate-resilient economy. We should continue prompting our partners to submit their updated nationally determined contributions and the long-term strategies of the Paris Agreement.  Thank you for the opportunity of having this debate, and I wish you every success in meeting the challenges ahead.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this has been a very interesting discussion, after the one we had last month, and I have listened attentively to your interventions. The discussion reflects the priority that the fight against climate change represents for all of us. These debates help us to shape a shared vision of the future. As we prepare for COP 25 in Madrid, everyone has to be determined and I can assure you that the European Union is.  Firstly, we want to finalise the Paris-Katowice Rulebook in Madrid. Secondly, we are preparing to update our nationally determined contributions (NDCs) next year. And thirdly, we are ready to mobilise additional financial flows in the coming years, as we have heard today. I can assure you that the Presidency will spare no effort to ensure that the EU will play a leading role in the work of the conference. name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: amtierende Ratspräsidentin. – Herzlichen Dank, sehr geehrter Herr Präsident! Ich brauche noch einen Moment, ich bin gerade gekommen. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Parliament for the invitation to take part in this debate, which addresses the very important issue of violence against women and domestic violence. This is particularly important today, the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women – that’s why we all have something orange with us.  Combating all forms of violence against women is a core element of respect for fundamental rights. In 2017, the Fundamental Rights Agency underlined the need for EU institutions and Member States to maintain their commitment to safeguarding the dignity of all women and girls in the European Union. The Fundamental Rights Report from 2019 encourages Member States to continue their efforts to effectively uphold victims’ rights and ensure rights awareness, access to appropriate support services, and effective remedies available to all victims of crime.  The Council has repeatedly expressed its commitment to preventing and eliminating all forms of violence against women, and it considers the Istanbul Convention a powerful tool in this fight. It’s a ground-breaking legal instrument, and monitoring of the implementation of the Convention has already shown that it is having a positive impact on the lives of women across Europe. As you know, Parliament, the Commission and the Council agree that the Istanbul Convention is a mixed convention which covers EU competences as well as Member States’ competences. Insofar as the Member States are concerned, we can note with satisfaction that by now all 28 Member States have signed the Istanbul Convention and that, to date, 21 Member States have also ratified it.  Insofar as the Union is concerned, on 11 May 2017, the Council decided that the European Union could sign the Convention. The Union signed the Convention on 13 June 2017. However, the proposed decision for the Union to conclude the Convention is still pending within the Council, together with the draft code of conduct setting out the arrangements between the Council, the Commission and the Member States for the implementation of the Convention.  The Finnish Presidency has continued working on the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention. The Union has signed the Convention, and the accession would enable better data collection and more accountability. We have also encouraged those Member States that still have not ratified the Istanbul convention to do so without delay. However, regard must be had to the fact that – as you are fully aware – in April this year, Parliament decided to request from the Court of Justice an opinion on the appropriate legal basis and the Council’s procedure for the accession to the Istanbul Convention. The Council will, of course, submit written observations to Parliament’s request for the Court’s opinion in due time.  On a more general note, the European Union protects women and children from gender-based violence through legislation and practical measures to defend victims’ rights. The 2012 Directive establishing minimum standards on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime, for example, places strong emphasis on access to appropriate support, including specialised support for women and children who have been victims of different forms of violence.  The European Union raises awareness of gender-based violence through co—funding campaigns run by national governments, and supports transnational projects run by non-governmental organisations that combat violence against women, children and young people. It facilitates the identification of common solutions among Member States by organising exchanges of good practices, and conducts research on gender-based violence.  I would like to conclude by reassuring you that the Council attaches great importance to this issue. The Presidency will continue working towards the conclusion of the Istanbul Convention by the European Union. We need to continue to seek solutions.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the occasion to discuss European Union accession to the Istanbul Convention and other measures to combat gender-based violence. First, allow me to congratulate the newly appointed co-rapporteurs on the file, Ms Spurek and Ms Kokalari.  Violence against women is widespread globally. Today’s International Day Against Violence Against Women reminds us again and again about the millions of victims of this phenomenon. The European Parliament and the Commission have always been strong allies in combating violence against women. The Istanbul Convention is an example of this cooperation: although we have not yet achieved our common main goal, Parliament’s strong stance has facilitated the role of the Commission and helped in keeping the European Union’s accession on the political agenda. I hope that this cooperation will continue in the future.  The Convention is the best available international legal tool for the protection of victims of gender-based and domestic violence through a joint European framework. The Commission President-elect clearly stated that European Union accession to the Convention remains a priority for the Commission in the new mandate. Twenty-one European Union Member States have already ratified the Convention. Based on the discussions so far in the Council working party, there should be enough support for a qualified majority of Member States to conclude also European Union accession. We should therefore remain committed to a swift ratification. Commissioner—designate Dalli has been mandated to finalise the ongoing accession process and, as she stated in her hearing in front of this House, she will do her utmost to achieve this goal.  In some Member States, national ratification was widely debated in public. The Commission will continue working with civil society organisations and the Council of Europe to rectify the misunderstandings and misconceptions spread during these debates. However, if unblocking the negotiations at the Council turns out to be an insurmountable task, the President-elect has confirmed that alternative ways to better support victims of gender-based violence and domestic violence will be explored. She also announced that the new Commission could look into the possibility of proposing minimum standards regarding the definition of certain types of violence.  The Victims’ Rights Directive is the main European Union law on victims’ rights. It provides for a set of rights for all victims of all crimes, including victims of gender-based violence. Although the Directive entered into application in Member States in 2015, most Member States still have not transposed it fully. Correct implementation of the Victims’ Rights Directive is a Commission priority. We need to ensure that all victims can rely on their rights, independently of where in the European Union the crime took place.  Legislation is not the only way forward: a comprehensive set of policy measures is needed to ensure that violence against women is tackled in a comprehensive and holistic manner. To provide the still—missing data on this phenomenon, Eurostat already started to work on a survey on gender-based violence in 2016. The questionnaire and methodology will be finalised by 2019 for the action to start in 2020 and end in September 2022 at the latest.

I want to believe that this is not a deliberate indoctrination aimed at uprooting the traditions of customs and replacing them with a vision of a reduced new man. Let us eliminate violence. Let us promote equality. But we also cherish differences. They are one of our European values.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr My friends, we're going to talk a lot more about gender, about gender, about power, about feminism. Because this is what this is all about. It is about us actually being able to change the gender power order. This stale patriarchal machism that generates violence against women, against girls and also against LGBTQ people. We are going to talk about it because we are going to create something new, so that we can put an end to violence against women and girls. This fight goes on every day, not just today. But what are we calling for today? We are calling for political action and for everyone to come together to do everything possible to put an end to this violence. We demand that the Member States ratify the Istanbul Convention. We are calling for consent legislation to be done at national level and we are demanding money to combat gender-based violence, especially in women's organisations and women's shelters, and you should know that on the other side of the right benches. We will not be silenced. We will not be silenced until we put an end to this violation of our human rights.

name: Belinda De Lucy (NI).
text: – Mr President, sexual violence against women and girls is being sanitised through language and it has to stop. Look no further than our courtrooms. The description of killing during sex as being ‘rough sex’ or ‘sex game gone wrong’ is being used as a defence in UK courtrooms and across the world. Fifty-six women in the UK have been killed by men who claim it was merely the result of ‘rough sex’. In the last five years, the defence has been used successfully in six out of 14 cases, that’s almost half. This is the message it sends out: if you kill a woman during sex, you can get off with a lighter sentence. As online porn tries to shock for more clicks, scenes are becoming more violent. We need to keep up with the effect this is having. Women who have been killed have no voice in the courtroom against the unpalatable defence of a ‘sex game gone wrong’. Grace Millane, 22 years old, was recently murdered in New Zealand and her killer’s version of events has gone unchallenged. My thoughts go out to her family. If we don’t name this crime accurately, we can’t fight against it properly, and not only does this mean no justice for murdered women but no deterrent for those that would murder them.

name: Ewa Kopacz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Violence not only against women, but against every person is a violation of his inherent dignity. Violence is contrary to the civilisational and cultural norms that we Europeans, for the most part, consider appropriate. Equality of all people before each other, rendition of domestic violence, in society, in the international community is an inevitable prospect of our civilization, and therefore a condition for its survival.  Recent protests by women in France, as well as the global #MeToo show an increase in awareness of this issue not only among women. I am deeply convinced that ratifying the Convention and persuading the public to send it to the public is our urgent task, a task for a good future. And that's what we're all about.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must confess that this evening's debate is a painful debate for me. It is a painful debate not only for the memory of the many women and sisters threatened, insulted, raped, killed by male violence, but it is a painful debate for the small presence of the members present, who did not even feel the need to pay tribute to the memory of these women. But it is a painful debate, ladies and gentlemen and dear President, also because of the violent and serious things I have heard from that side of the House. I find the words I have heard from my colleagues from the ECR, the ID Group and the right side of this House intolerable. It is intolerable to deny once again the urgency and the need to ratify the Istanbul Convention. One in three women, one woman in three, who could be your daughter, your sister, a friend of yours, is the victim of violence in Europe. So to accept once again that the urgency of ratifying this Convention is denied is unacceptable. So I think it is unacceptable, Mr President, to listen even more to the words we have heard in this House.  The time to act is now, never again postponements! So the countries that have not ratified the Convention – Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, the United Kingdom – are ashamed! (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, on 25 November 2019, I am appalled. I am appalled because in France this year, 138 women were murdered by their spouses. I am appalled that in Europe at least seven women are killed every day because they are women. I am appalled because, in the world, we do not even know how many femicides are committed. I am appalled to know that seven Member States have still not ratified the Istanbul Convention. This November 25, I have a thought for all these victims and their loved ones, because violence affects all women, of all ages, of all backgrounds, of all nationalities. They are called Rosa, Aurora, Maria, Natalia. They are Spanish, French, German, Greek. To combat all this violence, we have an instrument: the Istanbul Convention. So let's be Europeans! Let us defend our values and ratify the convention!

name: Isabella Tovaglieri (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one in three women worldwide at least once in their lives is the victim of physical or psychological violence. This violence is also being perpetrated in the countries considered to be the most advanced, where culturally backward areas still remain, not least because of uncontrolled migratory flows from territories where women are still considered to be deeply submissive. It is no coincidence that in Italy 67 % of feminicides are perpetrated to the detriment of foreign women. In Italy, however, thanks also to the red code wanted by the League, the strength and courage to denounce this violence has also increased. Italy has ratified the Istanbul Convention, but that is not enough, it is not enough, we need to do more. That is why I say that every day of the year must be considered as recalled as 25 November. Not only today, therefore, but also tomorrow, the day after tomorrow and every day of the year, we must fight for this battle of civilisation, which cannot be relegated to a single anniversary, after which the spotlight is turned off, but the violence continues every day.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, violence against women is something that must be strongly condemned. I personally believe that every man who assaults a woman is a scoundrel who deserves severe punishment. But that's not going to happen through this document. And it's not going to happen through this document because it wasn't designed to save women from violence. So far, I have heard hundreds of names of victims of domestic violence and they were from countries that have ratified, signed this Convention. What did she do to protect them? How did you help them? No, it didn't happen. Why? Because this document has another purpose and another task. This document mixed the legitimate theme of protecting women with absurd and controversial LGBTI ... the latter to close the door, propaganda, same-sex marriage, social role of gender. Perhaps I will surprise you, only that gender is not a social role and a construct. He's biology. Perhaps I will surprise you, but there are countries in Europe that still believe that family is a voluntary marriage between a man, a woman and their children, and we do not want this to change. I am from Bulgaria, we are against this convention, we have not signed it and we will not do so.

name: Miroslav Radačovský (NI).
text: – Mr President, dear friends, I have heard a number of flaming calls for the Slovak Republic to also be forced to ratify the Istanbul Convention. I'm asking why? Anyone who controls the legal order of the Slovak Republic and controls the Istanbul Convention must come to the unequivocal conclusion that all the objectives, even more, presented by the Istanbul Convention are already contained in the jurisdiction of the Slovak Republic. It is true that the Slovak Republic is committed to respecting human rights, respecting democratic principles by joining the European Union. However, it has not committed itself to joining the European Union, that it will lose the basic thing it has stated in the preamble to the Constitution of the Slovak Republic, namely that it was based on the principles of Cyrillic-Methodical, on the principles of national traditions and Christian traditions. That's the problem. There is no problem in violence against women, but in the vagueness of explaining some concepts. I worked in the territory of the Slovak Republic for forty years ... (the speaker exceeded the time granted).

name: Frances Fitzgerald (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we’ve heard the stories here tonight and we have to ask ourselves what is happening in our democracies that we still have this endemic level of violence against women. Right across every Member State, and indeed across the world, we have to do everything we can to call it out. No one person, no one institution is going to change this. It’s about many, many actors coming together to work to make a difference. We need policymakers, law enforcement officials, judges, social workers, sisters, brothers. We need male ambassadors who will work to make sure that we eliminate the violence that we’re hearing about tonight. Of the 28 EU Member States, seven Member States have still to ratify the Convention. What’s absolutely clear is that people are still ambivalent about the Convention, and we hear the projections onto the Convention. Let’s get back to basics. The Convention is about interrupting violence against women and using whatever means we can. We’re not implementing it for the institutions, we’re implementing it for sisters, daughters, wives ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Annika Bruna (ID).
text: Mr President, violence against women is a scourge that kills and which we must all fight against. This must be a priority.  However, this just cause is being misguided to impose an Istanbul convention that deals, of course, with violence against women, but also intends to impose a harmful ideology. Indeed, this convention aims to put gender theory in curricula at all levels of education, thus imposing smoking theses unrelated to women's rights. It also involves the international management of gender violence, in other words, giving asylum to the hundreds of millions of women who are victims of such violence worldwide. Unfortunately, this does not bring any real solutions to the countries of origin, and that is something we should be looking at. Finally, you want to force all Europeans to join the Convention, while seven Member States refuse to ratify it. The peoples of Europe intend to fight against violence against women, but they refuse to endorse the excesses.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy is one of the countries that has signed and ratified the Istanbul Convention, yet the figures are alarming: 142 women killed in 2018, 94 in the first ten months of 2019, 14 000 complaints of stalking, 17 000 of those for ill-treatment. But the situation in the other countries of the European Union is no better. It is 2019 and gender-based violence manifests itself in different forms, not only physical, not just psychological. Gender inequality is also wage inequality: think that women have to work 66 more days to earn like a man. What do these data mean? That more effort is needed, that the Convention must be properly applied, otherwise only fine words remain on a piece of paper. In Italy, we have now taken a great step forward with the Red Code Act, but further steps still need to be taken and here, in Europe, we must show the way. We need more investment in education, we need to fund anti-violence centres throughout Europe and, above all, we need to talk about them, to talk about them all the time and not just on 25 November.

name: Mathilde Androuët (ID).
text: This day is an opportunity for us women, MEPs and members of the Identity and Democracy group to highlight the extent to which violence against women is a constant concern, inseparable from the promotion of our model of civilization based on equality between men and women. However, lucidity obliges us to consider all sources of violence: at least 1,400 victims in Rotherham, England, by Indo-Pakistani gangs; 478 sexual assaults in Cologne by hordes of illegal immigrants during the 2015 celebrations; 52% of rapes committed in Paris are committed by foreigners. While it is obviously not exclusive, the share of non-Aboriginal aggressors in these acts is still significant. States or associations that are more ideological than feminist must stop downplaying the share of immigration in assaults on women. Opening the floodgates of immigration is increasing the threats to the plight of European women; to prevent women from saying so is to lock the victims of these assaults into a double punishment.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to the spontaneous speeches. I have almost twice as many speeches as we can take. I therefore ask for your understanding if I cannot take all of them into account. Spontaneous speeches

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Every woman has a right to be protected from violence. The most dangerous place for a woman is her home, where the perpetrators of violence are most common: as partners, as former partners, as members of the family. There are also sad things to report from my country, Austria: 18 women have already been murdered this year. Right now, the coming holidays are threatening to become particularly dangerous. After all, these are not family dramas, relationship tragedies, as is often reported, they are murders, they are crimes, and the Istanbul Convention offers protective measures to be applied here. It is about derailed fantasies of control, injured egos resulting from the fundamentally unequal distribution of power and resources in our society. We can do something about this by ratating the Istanbul Convention. This applies to Poland, to Austria, to Estonia, to Italy, to the whole of Europe.

name: Marcel Kolaja (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, since its adoption in 2011, we have witnessed numerous attacks targeting the Istanbul Convention. The opponents of the Convention misinterpret the scope. Talk about a limitation of freedoms and re-education of our children and it works. Just last week, our colleagues in the Czech Parliament received a letter calling for the immediate stop of the Convention.  There is nothing to be scared of, though. The Istanbul Convention is a significant cornerstone in the protection of women’s rights. It shall be a guarantee that, nowhere in Europe, domestic violence and violence against women are tolerated. The Convention gives us something very important – security that there will be no downgrading of the rights of women.  Governments change and even in the Visegrad Group (V4) we see calls from conservative circles to push women to have more children or to limit their rights to decide about their own body. This is something that just a few years ago would have been unimaginable. The European Pirates are extremely happy to support this document.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, I would believe in the Istanbul Convention to deal exclusively with violence against women, children or any other violence, not by imposing some new social norms. Indeed, if we wanted to fight violence against women, then we would not move women and children out of their home and create additional stress for them, but remove the abuser.  Colleagues, have you ever been to these safe houses? Do you think they're really safe? Do you know how many times an abuser broke into these houses, molested women in front of children, in front of other women?  And government associations wouldn't report it because they didn't get the money, they wouldn't get the money for it. So let's get the abuser out of the house. Let's get him to go to anger-control and then I'll believe something's going to happen. So when we fight violence like that, then I'm going to believe in the Istanbul Convention, and then abused women are going to report that violence a lot more.  And we're just playing with words.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, violence against women can take different forms with dramatic expression in domestic violence, but also in prostitution or violence at work. Measures leading to a public, articulated and decentralised response in its various dimensions need to be strengthened. The fight against violence against women is therefore inseparable from the elimination of labour exploitation, inequalities and discrimination between men and women, and is inseparable from the commitment to fulfil women's rights, to create the conditions for them to live, work and participate equally. In addition to combating the economic and social causes of exploitation, inequalities and discrimination, which in themselves feed and reproduce the various dimensions of violence, it is essential to face cultural factors, intervening to overcome prejudices and stereotypes, stimulating the change of behaviors and mentalities, raising the social awareness that equality in life is not only a just aspiration of women but also a condition of progress , social justice and democratization of peoples.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want zero tolerance for any form of violence against women. I am an emergency doctor and not once have I treated in Iasi at the Nicolae Oblu Emergency Clinical Hospital women assaulted, beaten, raped and I tell you today that rape also means violence. A woman who is raped at four hours is already too much for any European country, and in order to be truly effective these measures to prevent, combat, support victims, punish abusers must be the same throughout the European Union. I support this resolution by which all countries in the European Union must adopt the same legislative and political measures in order for these forms of violence to be combated, and I hope that this resolution is voted on on Thursday. I will personally vote for it with nine hands, and I also call on the Council and the European Commission to consider any rape as a crime and to have the same punishment because there is far too little talk of these abominable acts. Thank you and I hope you support this.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, to conclude, let me remind you why the European Union accession to the Istanbul Convention has been a priority for the current Commission and will be for President—elect and Commissioner—designate for Equality, Ms Dalli.  Too often we hear about women being killed, harassed or stalked by people close to them, children being abused or beaten by members of their families or harmed by persons they trusted. UN figures estimate that 137 women are killed per day across the globe at the hands of their intimate partner or a family member, and we all know that these figures do not represent the full picture of this unacceptable violation of human rights.  Violence is not always visible. Violence is perpetrated behind closed doors. Violence is perpetrated both with words and actions. Sometimes those words and actions are accepted just because they follow the logic of socially constructed gender roles and stereotypes. When the news opens our eyes or we become aware of violence being perpetrated right next door, in our communities, in our circles, in families we know, we feel powerless, astonished, shocked and angry.  The Istanbul Convention is nothing but a powerful instrument to react to this, to prevent violence against women, to protect the victims and give them justice. We owe this to the victims and survivors of those crimes.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to your valuable remarks and despite national and EU preventive actions, the prevalence of violence against women remains unacceptably high. It is clearly a common challenge to which we must respond.  The Finnish Presidency, like the previous ones, has invested a lot of effort into making progress towards the conclusion and ratification of the Istanbul Convention. The challenges and possible solutions to ratification of the Convention, both by the European Union but also by those Member States that have not ratified the Convention, should be openly discussed. Our Presidency has striven to keep such a discussion on the agenda and engage in dialogues concerning the ratification of the Convention.  This debate and the debate on women’s rights in general is not just a matter for women, it is our common cause. Women’s rights are human rights. Over this past weekend, tens of thousands of people took to the streets in Paris, in Rome, in Brussels and other cities. The message of our citizens is clear – violence against women has to stop. Everyone should feel safe. Everyone should be safe.  Our Presidency will continue working in any possible way towards this aim, and as the Presidency, we welcome the willingness of the incoming Commission to take the lead on this issue. Thank you again for this very important and valuable debate.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 November 2019. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Milan Brglez (S&D)
text: Writing. – Since 2016, the European Parliament has been the main supporter of the EU accession process to the Istanbul Convention through a number of debates and resolutions. It is essential that we insist and intensify the pressure on the European Commission and, in particular, on the Council, because there is an aggressive campaign against it in individual Member States (including some of those 21 that have already ratified the Convention). At the heart of this campaign is disinformation and lies about the content of the Istanbul Convention, which hinder the EU's accession to the Convention and the removal of reservations thereto. Opponents of the Convention are putting the fight against violence and advocating equality at a conflict with tradition and with the rights of the child, although the convention does not interfere with tradition, provided that it is not used as an excuse for violence or discrimination, and the rights of the child are strengthened at most. The scaremongering of populist right-wing movements before the convention stems from their awareness that the convention addresses the problem of violence against women and girls, as well as other vulnerable individuals, in a holistuous way, and through understanding and calling for the elimination of the structural causes of it. The latter is crucial, as women and girls in different environments are typically placed in a (including economic and social) submissive position and are therefore significantly more exposed to physical and psychological violence, which will not be eradicated without radical changes in thought and social patterns.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. Two and a half years after the EU signed the Istanbul Convention, we must go further in order to achieve full membership. We must make this very clear today, on international day for the elimination of violence against women; violence which constitutes a radical violation of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties. The numbers of women, girls and girls who are victims of violence, which manifests itself in different forms (physical, psychological, sexual violence, online violence), give us back the reality of a phenomenon dramatically widespread in European territory, but still certainly underestimated: too many women, in fact, do not denounce the violence suffered out of fear, shame, economic reasons or because they are "devastated" in their self-esteem by continuous mistreatment. This is especially the case when violence takes place in the context of emotional relations or within the home, often even in the presence of children, indirect victims of one of the most serious forms of gender-based violence. That is why it is important for the Union to accede to the Convention: to strengthen the prevention of gender-based violence, to provide protection and support for victims, to send out a clear and strong message against these intolerable violations of women's rights and dignity.

name: Anna Júlia Donáth (Renew)
text: Writing. – I come from a country whose powerful leadership has been unable for six years to legally legal the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Elimination of Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence. The Hungarian government denies the existence of domestic violence. Its authorities often explicitly hinder prevention and detection. In fact, the Hungarian police made a video entitled "You can do it, you can do something about it" of girls flirtatiously partying, indirectly suggesting that they too could be toy with their provocative behaviour. A doctor who attacked his ex-partner has had his genitals poured with corrosive fluid for six years. Now I've been convicted, but I've been acquitted twice before: after a series of abuses, they didn't keep me away from his wife, who he eventually killed. No man's rights would be narrowed if the convention were finally made law everywhere, including in Hungary, which, regardless of all ideologies, does only one thing: it protects women and children from physical violence. The range of victims, the scope for the perpetrators, would be narrowed. The accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention also has a concrete legal effect. The law of the Union must be in accordance with the Convention and EU law is binding on Hungary. I therefore call on everyone who cares about women's and children's rights to vote for the convention.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE)
text: Written. – Violence against women remains a huge challenge for the European Union. However, women should feel safe everywhere: at home, in public and online. This violence is a source of suffering and trauma, and at the same time determines the position of women in society: it affects their state of health, access to work and education and their participation in public life. This is diametrically opposed to the objective of the EU Treaties on gender equality.  Ursula von der Leyen rightly mentions the ratification of the Istanbul Convention as one of her Commission's top priorities. I would like to highlight three key points: 1. Up-to-date and comparative data: we need to be better able to know how many people are victims of what forms of gender-based violence. 2. Prevention and empowerment of women: on the one hand by tackling persistent gender stereotypes through education, awareness campaigns and professional guidance, on the other hand by monitoring perpetrators longer after their trial, depending on the high recidivism rates. 3. Specialised care centres: multidisciplinary centres, where victims can go for both medical and psychological help and can immediately report to the police. It is time we sent out a strong signal that women's safety is at the top of our agenda.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. – Violence is incompatible with both Christian or universal human values – it applies to any form of violence, even if it is domestic violence, which is most often violence against women. The consequences of this are long-lasting – it also damages and distorts our future generations, because it leaves deep traces in children. There is no justification for violence and it is suffering from it for society as a whole. Violence must not be distanced, considered as a norm or a 'domestic matter of the family'. It will not diminish itself. We must promote the co-responsibility of society and public institutions so that no child and adult have to live with the realisation that violence is normal or inevitable. We must help recover and refresh the victims of violence so that they can live a normal life. Latvia must also join a group of Western countries that condemn violence not only in words, but also in deeds. Do we really want to emulate the conservative majority of the Russian City Council, which, under the pretext of safeguarding 'traditional values', has on many times rejected amendments to laws that would classify domestic violence as a criminal offence? Already in 2016 Latvia signed this Council of Europe Convention. The task of the Latvian Saeima is to ratify this Convention and to further develop legislation to combat violence as an evil on a daily basis. The maturity of a democratic and modern society is the ability to be aware of and solve the problem.

name: Michal Šimečka (Renew)
text: Writing. – Violence against women is one of the most hesporting forms of human rights violations. The heinous act that recently took place in Slovakia in the ou00th thou of Viola Macáková is rightly shaking the public. According to research by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, one in three women in the EU will experience some form of physical or sexual assault from the age of 15. These are alarming facts. Nevertheless, some countries, such as Slovakia, are boycotting the ratification of the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. In such circumstances, how can opponents of this convention look women in the eye? On the occasion of today's International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, it is necessary to stand up clearly for women's rights and say: your security matters equally. Gender-based violence is a scourge that must be combated at all costs, for which legal instruments such as the Istanbul Convention are needed. I call on all, but especially the Members and voters of countries that have not yet ratified the Convention, to stop turning their backs on your women. Stop tolerating violence.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew)
text: in writing. – In Romania, more than 60% of us consider, according to UNICEF, that domestic violence is common, that it is part of everyday life. We live in a country where domestic violence is considered routine.  Romania ratified the Istanbul Convention in 2016, but we are far from being effective in preventing and combating domestic violence. In Bucharest, according to Romanian Police statistics, 5,096 temporary protection orders were issued between January and August 2019, with 1,850 being converted into final order. In 77% of cases it was domestic violence. According to the 2018 INSCOP study in Romania, every 30 seconds a woman is beaten, so every day, almost 3,000 women are assaulted. According to the General Inspectorate of Police, 32,696 cases of domestic violence were recorded in 2018. The women we're talking about here aren't just statistics. We need concrete action to prevent violence against women, to protect victims and to punish the guilty. We must work, both internally and europeanly, in a real and coordinated way, not hypocritical and populist, like the mayor of Bucharest, probably the only Social Democratic mayor in the world who has stopped funding the only emergency accessible shelter for victims of domestic violence.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation of Enik'gysri on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the agreement in the form of an exchange of letters between the European Union and Ukraine amending the agreements in the Association Agreement between the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community. trade preferences for poultry meat and preparations for poultry meat and preparations provided for by its Member States, on the one hand, and Ukraine, on the other (10720/2019 – C9-0105/2019 - 2019/0132(NLE)) (A9-0024/2019). I would like to remind you that requests for spontaneous speeches and blue cards can be made, both by means of the traditional procedure and by means of the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Enikő Győri
text: Artist. – Dear Mr President, Dear Commissioner, Colleagues, Allow me to begin with the greeting of Commissioner Hogan, who is here now as Commissioner for Agriculture, but in his capacity as Commissioner for International Trade, he will soon have a lot to do, I think, with Ukraine and with the ukrainian free trade issues. Ladies and gentlemen, today we are going to be talking about chickens cut strangely and a legal loophole. I would like to thank the Presidency of the European Parliament for finally circle the subject on the agenda of the plenary session. He has lessons to learn that make me think that this is really where the subject should be. What exactly is batman chicken? The Ukraine-EU free trade agreement concluded in 2016 allows imports of Ukrainian breast fillets within strict limits. There's a quota, and there's a heavy duty to pay. Yes, but there are two other lines of duty in this agreement that are not subject to quantitative limits or tariffs. At the time, he thought, in my opinion, that the Commission was not a problem, that it was such a small quantity. Yes, but on the Ukrainian side, some have taken advantage of this opportunity very cleverly and very mindfully, and have played out the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT with great creativity. Ukrainian businessmen brought in the chicken breast fillets with a small piece of bone, which had no customs duties or railings, and then they cut off these bones in the Union and put them on the market as breast fillets. While 3 700 tonnes of chickens of this type were introduced in 2016, in 2018 55 000 tonnes were already introduced thanks to this legal but tricky solution, which endangered the interests of EU producers and was a circumvention of the FTA. The Commission has entered into an exchange of letters with Ukraine to bring trade back into the regulated normal legal procedure by including the two customs lines concerned alongside the regulated breast filler and by increaseing the quota by 50 000 ton. I would also like to point out that health and veterinary standards have not been questioned, so the EU market was not in danger in this respect. In Ukraine, I can say that the government has already approved this amendment to the agreement, it was presented to parliament on 15 November. The relevant commissions have already discussed it and we are waiting for rada's plenary session to be put on the agenda as soon as possible. Finally, I would like to make a few requests. On the one hand, I ask the Ukrainian Parliament to hold the debate as soon as possible and to contribute to the agreement. I also ask ukraine, which is an important geostrategic partner for us, to trade with them fairly, to act in good faith, to apply it in good faith, and not to arregate the use of any loopholes or loopholes in the future. Finally, I would also ask the Commission to pay attention to the fact that the forthcoming free trade agreements do not include a loophole that allows them to be applied in bad will. Colleagues, I think that the Commission has found a good solution, and I ask that you vote in favour of the amendment to the agreement with Ukraine, so that we can protect the market and our own producers.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Ms Győri, and the shadow rapporteurs for their speedy work on this report, and I welcome the clear decision by the Members of the Committee on International Trade (INTA) to recommend that the European Parliament gives its consent to this agreement reached between the Commission and Ukraine earlier this year. I am grateful too for the favourable opinion by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) and I want to acknowledge the work of the rapporteur Mr Kuźmiuk. By giving consent to this agreement, the European Parliament is once again protecting the interests of our agricultural sector. Once Parliament has given its consent, the Council will have to adopt a decision on the conclusion of the Agreement.  As I’m sure you are aware, indeed it has been outlined very well by Ms Győri, the ratification process by the Ukrainian Parliament is still pending, even though the Ukrainian government agreed the agreement on 23 October last. We have been doing our best to encourage the Ukrainian parliament to proceed quickly with the ratification and I hope that they will do so when Parliament reassembles in Ukraine next week. In view of this likelihood and given the continued urgency of this issue, we are encouraging the European Parliament to give its consent this week so as to allow the completion of the ratification process from the European Union side.  You are all aware of the background, and this again has been outlined very well by Ms Győri and she has explained the sad and unsatisfactory history in relation to the poultry cuts issue. I want to assure Ms Győri that the European Commission will have learned lessons from this trading experience. The rapid increase in imports of the poultry cut in question did raise significant concerns due to the risk of potentially unlimited duty free amounts of poultry meat coming into the European market, particularly breast meat. In order to address these concerns, the Commission began consulting with the Ukrainian authorities last year and the agreement was concluded earlier this year. The solution provides for the inclusion of two particular tariff lines and the existing tariff rate quotas (TRQ) for poultry meat products, and an increase in the size TRQ by 50 000 tons, otherwise we would have an unlimited amount of poultry meat coming into the European Union in respect of breast meat. Out-of-quota imports under the other two problematic other cuts tariff lines would be subject to the most favoured nation tariffs.  Under the agreement reached, Ukraine is effectively accepting a limit to its exports of poultry meat into the EU, and while the increase of a quota by 50 000 tonnes is indeed substantial, it falls clearly below the current Ukraine export capacity of poultry breast meat. This agreement responds to a situation which threatened to present an enormous challenge to our EU poultry producers and I know that in your respective committees you have stressed the importance of monitoring closely the implementation of this agreement, which we will do. Not alone can I assure you on this point, but I also want to assure you that all of our Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) have been screened, that there are no further such loopholes relating to poultry lines involved in any previous agreements and we did not find any. We are committed fully to a continued close monitoring of the implementation of this and other FTAs and also, as you are aware, we are appointing a Chief Technical Officer in relation to trade implementation and enforcement in 2020.  While I welcome your acknowledgment that the agreement reached addresses the particular loophole, I do appreciate the concerns that have been expressed at the extent of the increase in the TRQ. I would point out, however, that the situation in question was monitored and identified at an earlier stage precisely because of this monitoring of our FTAs but nevertheless it is a substantial TRQ revision that has to be made in respect of this agreement.  I am grateful for the opportunity to contribute to this debate, to outline the background and also the action that we were taking, and also to thank again the Parliament for their anticipated consent to this agreement.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to begin by commending the European Commission for wanting to reach an agreement quickly with Ukraine on imports of poultry meat from this country into the Union. While the orderly arrangement of these imports entails a clear increase in the import quota for the country, it also offers hope of curbing imports outside it. However, the Committee on Agriculture expects the European Commission to introduce the possibility of protective measures in trade in agricultural goods into the agreement with Ukraine. Consequently, sanitary and phytosanitary requirements identical to those of agricultural products produced in the Union, as well as the need for Ukrainian producers to comply with animal welfare requirements, should be applied consistently to imported agricultural products from Ukraine.  At the same time, as a representative of Polish, a country neighbouring Ukraine, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that most of the agricultural goods originating in Ukraine imported into the Union under duty-free quotas end up on the Polish market and cause price competition, which seriously reduces the incomes of Polish farmers. The consequence of this should be additional EU support for Polish agriculture.

name: Christophe Hansen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I am very pleased to have the Commissioner here tonight in his actual position as Commissioner for Agriculture, but am looking forward as well to what is coming up in his new duties as Commissioner for Trade.  I want to reiterate that it was not the fierce success of the ‘Batman cut’ that made the EU chicken out of its commitments under the DCFTA. We believe that trade is a lever for economic development and can thus help to put a chicken in everyone’s pot. Yet, even if a 15-fold increase of imports of ‘Batman chicken cuts’ may have followed the letter of the agreement, it was not the intent to put our domestic poultry producers under such sudden strain. Therefore, I welcome this reasonable and negotiated settlement. The EU and Ukraine prove once again that the way forward in international trade is through negotiation, not unilateral actions.  I clearly hear you, Commissioner Hogan, that the Commission intends to properly close the mazes of the fence in order to make sure that such loopholes no longer occur in the future.

name: Marek Belka
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Association Agreement with Ukraine and the DCFTA are vital instruments for promoting the modernisation of Ukraine and engaging it in closer cooperation. The import quotas on a number of products were set up in good faith: to lend a helping hand to Ukrainians faced with the collapse of its trade with Russia.  The exploration of a loophole in the EU tariff system involving some Ukrainian companies caused serious imbalances in our poultry sector in Poland. Sadly, it took the Council and the Commission as much as two years to effectively tackle this problem. We welcome, however, the new tariff agreement reached between the Commission and Ukraine. We have to remember, however, that our rules need to be more precise with regard to future trade agreements, and that the European authorities have to act more efficiently in monitoring and acting on the implementation of our agreements.

name: Karin Karlsbro
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Free trade is the basis on which EU cooperation is based. It is through trade that we create and maintain peace and prosperity in Europe, and that is how we forge the strongest ties outside the European Union. However, free trade requires rules – rules that take account of the respective parties' circumstances and make trade fair. When rules-based trading works, it is a powerful tool that benefits everyone. When it emerges that the rules that we have jointly laid down do not work, it goes without saying that, as a free trade friend, you have to be involved in taking responsibility and correcting them. This is precisely the situation in the case of the chicken within the framework of the Deep Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine, where it turns out that it has not worked. We must overcome this kind of loophole that undermines the whole idea of rules-based trade. Ukraine is a very important strategic partner for the EU, and the EU, in turn, is Ukraine's largest trading partner. Both parties thus benefit from the fact that trade between us is well organised. That is why we find it completely uncontroversial to support this change, and we see that both parties benefit from it.

name: Sarah Wiener
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I see it a little differently. It is a bit controversial: we all support Ukraine's efforts to fully implement the Association Agreement. But it is a bitter pill that the Ukrainian poultry giant MHP, which speaks of itself as a game changer for the global chicken industry and wants to do more business in the KEY markets of the EU, is benefiting, so to speak, from its successful bone trick and is being rewarded with a sharp increase in the duty-free export quota. It is said that this has at least plugged a loophole. But let's face it, I say it's just unfair that a fraudulent trade flow is legalised. It should be borne in mind that the conditions under which livestock farming in Ukraine does not meet European standards, thus creating an unfair competitive situation with regard to EU farmers. They will continue to earn oligarchs who are unfairly competitive for small-scale farms ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mazaly Aguilar
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, the chicken sector in Europe is one of the most systematically harmed in trade agreements. Mercosur is an example of mistreatment of this sector. Therefore, the amendment of the Trade Agreement with Ukraine was urgent and necessary. From Russian veto to Ukrainian products, Ukraine has concentrated its exports of meat, chicken, to the European Union, including new cuts that were introduced into the European Union as what they were not. I hope that this Agreement will give more security to operators in the sector, and I hope that the European Union will be able to have the same flexibility to change concessions to Mercosur in this sector.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, even before the conclusion of the Association Agreement with Ukraine, there were warnings about the dumping of Ukrainian flop chickens on the European market. However, the treaty was pushed through, including a huge error that allowed flopping chicken giant MHP to transport unlimited chicken to Europe. Can you say whether there was any intent involved in the making of this error, or dare the Commission to admit that it made a huge mistake in the negotiations?  Ukraine refuses to take this error out of the treaty unless the EU accepts a mega quota of 50 000 tonnes of additional chicken. A disgrace! The European Commission indicated months ago that the company MHP does not comply with our environmental and animal welfare rules. How can you allow this? Surely you know that this is at the expense of European farmers, the environment and the local residents of these gigastals?  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Иво Христов (S&D).
text: – Dear Commissioner, over the past three years the European chicken market has become the subject of unfair competition from Ukraine through unregulated imports of products. The proposed measure to cap duty-free imports for the product line concerned is a logical step. In essence, however, with the set increase of 50 000 tonnes, we will allow almost the same amount that was imported into the European market from Ukraine in 2018. This approach does not guarantee the interests of European producers.  I call on the European Commission to start work on assessing the impact of the Association Agreement on European agriculture. In my country, serious pressure from Ukrainian honey is felt by beekeepers and they lose their livelihood. Oil crop producers are also concerned. We must not allow European agri-producers to fall victim to the union's overall policy, free trade dogmas or political considerations.

name: Bert-Jan Ruissen (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the deal with Ukraine on poultry meat does raise very mixed feelings. It is true that the loophole in the agreement is being closed, but we must make a very generous concession of 50 000 tonnes of poultry meat. As far as we are concerned, the poultry sector deserves better treatment, especially as it is already facing increasing cheap imports, with serious concerns about compliance with our standards. Why was there no clause in the treaty to prevent circumvention of the quota? Is such an emergency clause in it now or does the risk of a new escape route remain life-size? What about animal welfare in Ukraine, by the way? And when will Ukraine meet our European requirements? I would very much like to clarify this, because at the end of the day it is a level playing field for our farmers.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
