text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to say that there are two parts to this point for me. One is business and the other is political. This trade means balancing certain risks resulting from the implementation of existing agreements with Ukraine. Here it is clear that there were some gaps. I am glad that both the rapporteur and the Commissioner have clearly described them. It is clear to me that we need to bridge these gaps, and I think this is a good result. I'd like to support that. The second part is political support for Ukraine, because I think that we must unequivocally support Ukraine. Many citizens of Ukraine, but of course also of its institutions, are waiting for this support to be expressed. This is one of the measures that can help. As much as I perceive that our European interests are here, there is a political commitment towards Ukraine, and we should fulfil that. I subscribe to this because I also supported this association agreement here in the last period.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is wonderful that Mr Hogan has managed to make these rules valid for all, and I wish that these things for the protection of farmers and the European system would always be valid. And if I keep noticing this flexibility, I take this opportunity, my honor committee, it is about the agricultural subsidy. I ask you when you will show the same flexibility to Romanian farmers who have only half of the European subsidy. Thank.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I obviously come from the same country as the Commissioner and wish him good luck with his job but, Commissioner Hogan, you have a huge capacity and potential to make a positive impact for farmers and food producers across Europe. But you also have the potential to do them serious damage. If the European system is going to prevail with importing material from outside of Europe at the expense of food producers in Europe, I don’t think that has to be the way forward. We are going to put small farmers and small producers out of business if ‘cheap’ is the law that rules every day.  Of course there’s cheaper production available from outside of Europe because they’re getting paid peanuts in the production process, but that is no reason, Commissioner, for you to go down that track. You need to protect farmers, especially small farmers and small producers across Europe.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, I do not wish to blame the Commission's negotiators too much, but it must be acknowledged that the Ukrainians did have us. European poultry farmers, already under pressure, are paying dearly for this European naivety, which will continue to pay dearly for the long term, since Ukraine has obtained an additional quota of 50,000 tonnes in this case. Personally, I regret that the request of the Committee on Agriculture has not been taken up, namely the introduction of a safeguard clause called 'next generation'. Having said that, as you said, Commissioner, this text puts an end to a situation that was out of control and, of course, we must give our assent to it.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, can I again thank those who contributed to this evening’s debate. I know that people are certainly more informed now in relation to the background, but also on what we have done to try and correct this particular problem which was unforeseen at the time of the negotiations, but legally this particular loophole was exploited and it is now corrected.  We’ve also followed up with all of the other free trade agreements (FTAs) in relation to poultry and other lines to ensure that a similar situation doesn’t happen in those particular respective FTAs. So I’ve listened carefully and I do understand the concerns about having to concede 50 000 tonnes of additional quota of poultry meat from Ukraine, but at the same time there would have been an unlimited amount of poultry coming into the European Union otherwise.  As you know, one of the priorities of the new Commission is to establish this position of the Chief Enforcement Officer and this person will operate under DG TRADE and will have a very important role in ensuring the implementation and enforcement of all of the FTAs that we have to date. I could tell you that the Commission has prepared a draft implementing regulation which has already been discussed with Member States. This could be adopted in time for the opening and management of this additional quota by 1 January 2020, and for the sake of clarity, it is also worth making the point that the quota will be managed by a system of import licences, as is the case for the existing quotas of poultry meat. Just turning to a few of the points raised by the speakers. Ms Hazekamp and Mr Bert-Jan Ruissen have rightly pointed out to various issues in the Netherlands and the concerns that your poultry producers would have. The same can be said of France and Poland.  One point five million tonnes of poultry come into the European Union every year because we have a deficit in poultry in the European Union. Three million tonnes of an increase in consumption of poultry has been happening over the last three years in the European Union. That’s not to say that there are some producers in some countries where we have a high concentration of poultry which we certainly have to be conscious of.  In the Association Agreement reached, Ukraine has committed to approximate its sanitary and phytosanitary and animal welfare legislation with that of the European Union, and once this is concluded and implemented, Ukraine will be the first third country exporting significant volumes of poultry meat to the EU that applies EU welfare standards throughout the production chain. We have recently had a strategy meeting in relation to this and there has been an adoption by the EU-Ukraine SPS Subcommittee on 18 November 2019 where the strategy has been agreed between the EU and Ukraine.  And I’m sorry to say to Ms Hazekamp that I don’t think the common agricultural policy is going to be abolished. You will probably be on your own – 99% of the people here, I think, agree with that particular outcome. Can I finally say to my friend Mr Wallace from Wexford that we have to have continued exports of food and farm products from the island of Ireland: 90% of what we produce we export. If you want the thousands of jobs in Wexford to continue in the food sector, we have to continue exporting – and at the end of the day you will be doing so on the same level playing field as the EU standards. No product comes into the European Union without meeting EU standards. And if you want to close down food processors and particular people involved in the food sector in Wexford, you should tell them that, and the Wexford people, and maybe the Enniscorthy Echo as well next week.

name: Enikő Győri
text: Artist. – First of all, I thank Commissioner Hogan for informing us of good news. I think that the use of the lessons of this matter in the conclusion of further free trade agreements and the review of the previous ones is certainly encouraging. Just as it is encouraging that negotiations are continuing with Ukraine on plant health, veterinary and animal welfare issues. I know that Ukraine wants to renew the free trade agreement, I think that this will all serve as a lesson for the future. Ladies and gentlemen, several of you have argued that this is a very serious quota increase, can we talk about the fact that this extra 50 000 tonnes, this is a lot or a few, the glass is half empty or half full. I think that the most important thing is to push back into a regulated, legal framework what is not the letter of the law, the text of the convention. Unfortunately, what Ukraine has done, but it has done trickery, it has done a trick, and we are eliminating it, so it is very important that this amendment takes effect as soon as possible. We've just talked about veterinary and health issues. I would like to reassure Mr Kuzmiuk, so this matter is not related to this at this time, but I think what he has raised is very important, yes, we will have to pay attention to them. I, as head of the monitoring road on Ukraine in the INTA Committee, will pay particular attention to this. Finally, I am glad that the left has discovered the farmers themselves, and I am glad to be told that it is important for them, too, that the interests of European farmers prevail. I hope that these Members, when we talk about the common agricultural policy, its reform and the green economy, will still be willing to represent the interests of European farmers and European farmers. Thank you very much, and I would ask everyone to vote tomorrow in support of the amendment to the Free Trade Agreement by exchange of letters.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 26 November 2019. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – Ukraine is an important geopolitical and geostrategic partner for the European Union. The EU is Ukraine's largest trading partner, covering more than 40% of its trade in 2016. Ukraine accounts for 0.9% of total EU trade, with a turnover of €29.6 billion in 2016. We must ensure that trade between the EU and Ukraine works in good cooperation.  Poultrymeat and its products are considered to be sensitive products in the EU and are therefore subject to duty-free tariff quotas. It is therefore regrettable that the Association Agreement initially left a loophole. This led to the EU starting to receive a dramatic increase in the number of poultry cuts covered by two unprotected tariff series, which, following a small change in the EU market, were sold off on the EU market as poultry breast meat, a sensitive product and covered by a tariff quota. I support the abolition of the loophole in the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement as soon as possible. This will ensure that trade in poultrymeat becomes more rules-based and protects the interests of EU producers by granting protection against possible unlimited imports of poultrymeat.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – I agree with the conclusion of a treaty with Ukraine to increase the tariff quota for poultrymeat. This Treaty aims to allow imports of poultrymeat while protecting European poultry farmers and consumers. The Treaty provides for an increase of 50 000 tonnes of the current quota (18 400 tonnes). This means that total imports of poultrymeat will be up to 68 400 tonnes. On the other hand, imports of 'poultrymeat cut-outs' will be included in this quota. This lower quality part of poultry will not be able to be imported duty-free, as is the case today. On the basis of the new quota, the quantities of imported poultrymeat from Ukraine shall be stabilised. In the last two years, imports of 'cut-out poultrymeat' imported outside the quota have increased to 55 000 tonnes per year. The treaty will also ensure compliance with health and veterinary standards by Ukrainian breeders in order to protect our consumers. It is equally important to help Ukraine. For Ukraine, we are the largest export market. In this way, the EU can help a neighbouring state in a difficult situation. Support for Ukraine as an important geopolitical partner is essential. Overall, 50 000 tonnes of poultry have a negligible share of the EU market. On the contrary, we should consider whether the EU should reduce imports from countries such as Brazil, from where we import more than 360 000 tonnes of poultrymeat per year.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew)
text: In writing. I regret that a sensitive product , here poultry meat - has been directly the victim of a malfunction of the trade agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. After the agreement came into force, Ukrainian exports of this piece of poultry to the European Union increased 15-fold in two years, without tariffs. The exponential increase in duty-free imports of this particular piece of poultry meat (from about 3,700 tonnes in 2016 to more than 55,000 tonnes in 2018) has raised serious concerns. How could the Commission allow this error to pass through during the negotiations and at the time of the conclusion of the agreement? There is therefore clearly a problem in the Commission's method of negotiating sensitive products. Particular vigilance should have been given to this sensitive product from the outset of the negotiations. It also reminds us of the crucial importance of monitoring the implementation of the EU's trade agreements. The imminent arrival of a head of the application of trade laws to the Commission should enable immediate intervention and solutions in the event of a malfunction or non-compliance with an agreement.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's declaration on the 30th anniversary of the velvet revolution: the importance of the struggle for freedom and democracy in Central and Eastern Europe for the historic integration process in Europe (2019/2931(RSP)). We welcome Commissioner Jourova to this item on the agenda. Before giving the floor to Mrs Jourova, I would like to point out once again that requests for spontaneous speeches and blue cards can be made, both by means of the traditional procedure and by means of the electronic system. As always, instructions are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to join Members to celebrate and reflect on the 30th anniversary of the revolutionary year 1989, which marked the beginning of the end of totalitarian regimes in all central and eastern Europe. Today’s European Union is built on the ruins of the Berlin Wall, on the spirit of the Solidarity movement in Poland, on the Baltic Way and the Velvet Revolution in the former Czechoslovakia. The accession of 2004 allowed us to reconcile our continent’s geography with its history and a collective wish to share its future together.  I vividly recollect 1989. We, the people in Czechoslovakia, wanted change. We wanted to come back to Europe, and I am convinced that it was not in search of material goods. It was especially in search of its freedoms. To live in freedom was a dream we all shared in Europe, but in the east it has become a reality later than in the west and the south. Living in freedom requires a process of adjustment, not only to the immediate benefits of individual liberties, but also to the meaning of individual responsibility and the constant process of debate and compromise, discussion and change which is inherent in democracy.  Our societies are now wealthier. We live longer, we can educate ourselves better, and we have immensely better choice. Our administrations are healthier when democratically accountable. Through that and the checks and balances assured by independent justice, the rule of law and fundamental rights, we live in a fairer, more just society built on common values which provide liberty, security and stability for its citizens, and therefore a better life. Yet, especially in times of uncertainty, there are those who peddle old lies and play to the insecurities of people. They point to a past that never was and promise a future that will never come. They say it requires the rule of a strong leader and they offer simplistic solutions to complex problems. Democracy is an invincible ideal, but also a fragile system and it is certainly not a given. We need to cherish and defend our European values, to maintain Europe as a resilient, assertive player standing firm on its pillars of liberal democracy, an inspiration and an example of a better way for people to govern themselves.  It is naive to believe that the democratic change we made after the revolution is irreversible. Democracy is a process. It has no end and it needs constant maintenance. With humility we should accept that, as politicians, we cannot protect the values alone. We need a robust and vigorous civil society and active citizens – not just consumers – to join us in our vigilance against authoritarianism and the efforts of authoritarian powers to interfere in and undermine our democracies.  We need to nurture our democratic institutions and our citizens’ confidence and trust in them, and in us as part of these institutions. The greater our institutions’ resilience, an independent judiciary, law-bound and accountable legislators and executive – and also of course free media and civil society – the stronger will be our democratic and self—confident Europe.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, 30 years is a very long time, although it may not seem like it to those who were in the squares at the time. Let me share the three inspirations that this time has for me. First, let us remember that communism did not collapse on its own. Without thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of courageous people who were spreading ideas of democracy and freedom even then, he would not have collapsed.  The second thing, in these very divided times, let us remember how great it was when most of society was united by thoughts of a better future. A future that respects important values. And let's remember how much we seem to miss it today. And for the last time, let us remember that we have built a rich company, but we have succeeded less in building a company that is coherent and resilient. However successful we have been in very important things, we are part of a common Europe, we are involved in shaping it and we live in the best place in the world today. At the same time, however, it is great that the past few days have shown that among young people, the ideas that helped us overcome communism are still alive and willing to fight for them.

name: Robert Hajšel
text: for the S&D Group. – Madam President, freedom of expression, assembly, travel, business, but especially free elections are the eeries of the Velvet Revolution and democratic change in Europe. Personally, I am pleased that in 1989 we rang a totalitarian regime that, especially in the 1950s, bloodily suppressed freedoms and later choked many people only for expressing their political opinion. I am pleased that, thanks to the Velvet Revolution, we later became part of the European Union. However, it has to be said that not all people's expectations have been met. Many have lost their jobs, their homes, and even today, decent housing is not a matter of course. According to many, promises have not been fulfilled that there will be no more expensive, redundancies or the sale of strategic industries and energy. That is also why I would like us to use this round anniversary, in addition to well-deserved celebrations, to debate across the political spectrum how to combat corruption more effectively, how to increase law enforcement and, in particular, how to strengthen social conveniences, in one word, how to make the whole of the European Union a better place to live. After all, dialogue was one of the priorities of the actors of the Velvet Revolution.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: for renew. – Madam President, my generation is actually the last to be born into communist Czechoslovakia. We were lucky to be the first to go through the transformation of our country, and we were the first to grow up in a democracy. We had new opportunities, we could study, we could look freely into the world. We could say what we wanted. We could think what we wanted to be and be what we wanted to be. None of this has ever been self-evident to our parents' generation. I have no doubt that, despite all the scacies, our young generation, our new democracy, has taken the right path. I am grateful for it and I am happy that our children have been born into a free country for 30 years. But we should remind them of how precious a gift it is and how important it was to us, and still is, the fall of 1989. The moment that brought us back to the democratic part of the world, a democratic Europe, gradually led us to NATO and the European Union.  By the way, when I first arrived in Brussels, states were divided into 'new' states and 'old' states. It was a cliché when our Central Europe was perceived as an inexperienced student. I think Central Europe has grown up. We have done a great deal of work and I would like to thank and pay our respects to all those who stood at the beginning of this journey.

name: Marcel Kolaja
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, today we commemorate the anniversary of the Velvet Revolution, a non-violent positive change of regime in Czechoslovakia. Thanks to our previous generation, we live in a free society and we managed to integrate well into the European structures. However, the current generation needs to address another difficult task – to cope with the misuses of the tools the digital era brings and to ensure that our state works for everyone equally and is not providing benefits only to a few. Twice this year, more than 250 000 people gathered in Letná Park in Prague to express their willingness to defend our democracy and liberties in the biggest demonstrations in the Czech Republic since 1989. A memento of the Velvet Revolution is protection of freedom. I strongly believe this cannot be silenced and that in the end, as Václav Havel said: ‘Truth and love will overcome lies and hatred’.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, I would also like to see another point of view that is neglected in the context of November 1989. First of all, it must be said that the people in the squares wanted democracy, not capitalism, as evidenced by the December 1989 survey. Citizens were maintained by the November protagonists in the hope that the bad things would end and the good would continue. Instead, the road to the destruction of huge state property by a group of tunnellers who still laugh at Czech citizens has opened up. In many ways, our country has become a cheap assembly company with three times lower wage levels than in Germany or Austria. Hundreds of thousands of executions, a million people in the poverty zone, children who have to be treated, or astronomical housing prices may not be entirely positive in the 30-year report card of the current regime. Reminding us of the past is possible, but it won't make our future any better.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am extremely proud to commemorate this important anniversary in the EP today. Thirty years ago, together with many friends, I stood in the square as a citizen of a totalitarian state and together we tried to fight for freedom. Today, together, we are part of a united, free and democratic Europe. It's a miracle for our generation. It is a miracle that would not have been possible without many victims. Therefore, let me recall and remember the hundreds of priests and churchmen who were forced to carry out forced labour in prison. To the thousands of peasants to whom the regime took land and so nourished the rest of their lives. Or the 270 people killed - who only wanted to go to another country and were shot on the Iron Curtain. No, communism is not a fairy tale where everyone gets what they need. It is a criminal ideology that has destroyed the lives of half of Europe. Let us do everything we can to ensure that this time does not come back out of respect for these victims.

name: Attila Ara-Kovács (S&D).
text: - Madam President, dear Colleagues, There are many members of our Parliament who have been active participants in the democratic regime change that took place in 1989 in the eastern part of the continent. I am one of them, and although our czech and Slovak friends are the first to pay their respects at this moment in connection with the Velvet Revolution, all eastern Europeans, and indeed all European Democrats, have embraced that revolution and can feel it today. But looking back 30 years, the picture is not clear and in many respects it has raised serious concerns. In the last ten years, an undemocratic regime change has taken place in Eastern Europe, and it is very painful for me, as a Hungarian, that my country is at the forefront of this counter-rotation. If there is a task, a mission of the European Parliament, it is to keep our society, to keep europe's great and common society on the trajectory set by the Velvet Revolution, and which at that time rejected illiberalism and populism, which today's advertisers were still planning, how they would afede with all the promises of our newly acquired freedom.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Thirty years ago, a strong wind of change blown over our continent. The biggest peaceful coup in post-war Europe began. It was a real opportunity, the driving force of which was human solidarity. Many events come to mind as symbols of that period, the round table to which the representatives of the opposition Solidarity and the government side in Poland sat, is the fall of the Berlin Wall, in the velvet revolution of Czechoslovakia could be the sight of Karel Gott, a favorite of the socialist regime, singing for hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Wenceslas Square in Prague. In 1989, the citizens of Central and Eastern Europe made an informed choice, chose freedom and democracy, elected Europe. Communism is no longer a threat to us these days, but extremism is so. When we open newspapers, we read that judges of tribunals are being removed by politicians, the media controlled by governments, so we cannot passively accept how some governments are trying to lose what we have succeeded in. We must remember that democracy is not given once and for all, that democracy is like a beautiful flower – nurtured flourishes, neglected withers.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: This brings us to the spontaneous speeches. We already have 15 registrations, but actually only five minutes. That is why I have now selected six colleagues , across all the political groups , in order to cover virtually all areas.  Spontaneous speeches

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today is exactly 30 years ago, when 800,000 people gathered in Prague demanding the end of one-party rule. This miracle, which I call a miracle in the name of the revolution, was caused by the sacrifices of thousands of people, but also by hard work and a number of sacrifices that had to be made. In recent years, the countries behind the Iron Curtain have had to overcome a number of obstacles, including by succeeding in joining the European Union. This anniversary should lead us to understand what unites us, or why, on the contrary, new barriers are being created and how to face these barriers, whether some call it social dumping or protectionism. We in Central Europe should not forget the value of freedom, democracy and the rule of law. Along with the students, we should say, "Thanks for being able to. Thank you for your freedom."

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to pay tribute to the role of artists, intellectuals and students in the Velvet Revolution. They offered important reflection, new perspectives, courageous thinking, and a space for civil society to be nurtured and grow. The playwright Václav Havel was a key figure in the peaceful transition of what was a one-party Communist state to a fully-functioning European democracy.  Other inspirational leaders have stood up against authoritarianism and dictatorships all around the world, providing a light in the dark when there was none. Without those brave creative muses, where would we be now?  In this moment of profound reflection, I’d like to ask Ms von der Leyen once again if she will amend the portfolio title of the Commissioner-designate Gabriel to Innovation, Youth and Culture.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, 30 years since the fall of communism, we often forget lightly how violent and opposed this system was to all that we consider to be a civilizational reach. In post-communist states, nostalgic voices, interestingly enough, mention only industrialization and what kind of security, but they skillfully avoid talking about systematic human rights violations and regime violence that crossed state lines.   Croatian political emigrants have thus been liquidated by Yugoslav intelligence around the world. Opponents of the regime were nowhere safe, even as full-fledged citizens of democratic, Western states.   Even today it is important to talk about this so that new generations know all the evils of communism and socialism. It's not about a system of social justice and equality, it's about a criminal regime whose human life is a mere statistic and has killed millions of people.

name: Martin Hlaváček (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I was almost ten years old at the events of November 1989. We lived near where the special forces were coming from. I remember to this day how two emotions alternated in the eyes of my parents, but also in their voices. It was fear, and it was hope. Hope has prevailed. We had free elections, freedom of speech, we shared with our Slovak colleagues, but that was only to find each other again in the European Union and in NATO. With the fall of the Iron Curtain and the end of the Cold War, history did not end, even though we might have thought so for a while. Freedom is not a matter of course today, the fight for human rights is not a struggle of the past. We shouldn't forget that. What does this mean for us? We should not forget all the sacrifices that have been made over the decades so that we can be here today, part of a free and democratic Europe, and fight for these ideals for the future. We should also not make wrong decisions. If we look around us, at Crimea, or if we look at the latest decision on the Balkans, we need to remember these facts.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I’m all for celebrating freedom and democracy but it strikes me that we’re very selective in our celebration. I wasn’t here last year, but I doubt very much there was a 50th anniversary celebration of the revolution in France or the civil rights movement in Ireland or the anti-Vietnam protests, yet week after week in here, we have the uprisings of the people of eastern Europe being used to justify a narrative of the poor victims of Eastern Europe being freed from the big bad wolf of communism and brought into the loving arms to live happily ever after in the European Union. Well, I don’t see that narrative as being a reality. Let us remember here when we have a balanced view of history that according to the Lancet a million adults died prematurely as a consequence of the imposition of capitalism in Eastern Europe. Is this just a statistic? The giving away of public property to oligarchs, was that in inevitability? Is that what people were struggling for? So I think when we look at our history, we have to look at it in a fair and balanced way and learn the lessons correctly.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, on every occasion the European Union and its Parliament, their governments are setting up anti-communist fiestas to speed up the implementation of their anti-communist plans on the basis of the provocative and dangerous September resolution for the people. Anti-communist measures, persecution and the overturning of historical truth are a prerequisite for the escalation of the unpopular attack in order, without the hotelier, to have a free field to claim that no other way than capitalist barbarism exists.  Communist intervention documents that peoples can live without poverty, without unemployment, without rubber work, without imperialist wars, refugees, without health/education/housing-goods, without capitalist exploitation. Thirty years later, the peoples who, despite the hot money you are spreading, can now compare the unpopular politics they experience with what they had then and lost. We are sure that the people will eventually find their way, by fighting their own, with powerful communist parties, to gain power.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Mr President, I would like to thank you for your – Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I cannot resist saying my final word in my native language, which is also the language of the playwright, writer, dissident Václav Havel, who wrote a script for us, czechs and Slovaks, for a free country. We didn't always play the script. I think there is always time to reflect how we have used democracy and freedom and whether we have worked hard enough on it, because democracy and freedom must be worked on. It's not an automatic thing. I was very impressed when you some of you were talking about how you remember 1989 and that it was like a miracle. I also remember the euphoria that came when we understood that we would finally get rid of the totalitarian regime that distorted morality, which, for example, forced me to think seriously about how I would explain to my six-year-old son that he must not say outside what he hears at home. A number of other things we got rid of may be worth remembering again. It is not true what is being said today when we remember the 30th anniversary or when we remember the revolution, that communism collapsed on its own. It's not true. We were, I personally did not, but many people were persecutioned, very courageously opposed to the regime, many people gave their lives. I think that we are all committed today not to squandering those sacrifices and to continue the work, hopefully, on peaceful and democratic terms. Let's look to the future. As we analyse the present, we see that we have problems in Europe. As Vice-President of the European Commission, if the new Commission receives support from you, responsible for values and transparency, I will be responsible precisely for value principles such as democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, of course human rights, freedom of the media and the promotion of an active civil society. I think we have to work all this out, we have a number of problems in Europe, we have a suddenly returning principle in the minds of many that the winner takes everything after the elections. The belief is beginning to creep in that the one who lies better wins the election, the one who has more dirty money and uses more dirty methods, including the use of digital conveniences, wins the election. We have a number of new warning trends concerning both the media and the business model for independent media, which report that they are having great trouble maintaining. These are all things that we will have to work on together, and I am prepared, of course, to work intensively in my new position. I think we all have a duty to ensure that some elections in Europe are not the last, and we have a duty to ensure that people can count on it. At the same time, I must conclude by saying that we must also work very hard to ensure that the citizens of the European Union are with us in this endeavor, so that they understand what we are doing and why we are doing it when we are working for democracy, freedoms and human rights. So that we do not stay like the proverbial stake in the fence and czech colleagues know what I am talking about. We have to explain, but we also have to do a lot to make people in Europe feel like they are in countries where they have their certainty that they do not have to live in constant fear of the future. We know that our current society is really shaken by a great deal of uncertainty and a sense of injustice. I fear that people who are at risk of execution, people who calculate that, while our gross domestic product is increasing, the poverty rate remains the same, working parents who cannot pay their children a decent life, all these people may not have as much desire to think about why we need to fight for democracy, human rights and all those noble principles. I think we have a lot of work to do on many fronts and I would like us, together with the European Parliament, to turn our forces in the right direction. I'm personally prepared for this.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The reality of recent decades beresfully behalffully the triumphalist proclamations that followed the defeats of socialism in eastern Europe. Capitalism not only proves incapable of solving the problems that humanity faces, but tends to aggravate them to the point of jeopardising the very existence of humanity. The defeats of socialism have not changed the essence of capitalism, but have made its unjust and inhuman nature more evident. Europe and the world have not been safer, on the contrary. The "new world order" proclaimed by imperialism brought war, which is a threat that permanently weighs on workers and peoples. Contrary to what we were assured, history did not end 30 years ago. Although it continues to be written and rewritten to the prevailing economic and political interests - and this debate is quite a demonstration of that, - those who announced the end of the class struggle have confused desires with reality. Some of humanity's most prodigious endeavors required time, advances and setbacks, victories and defeats. This will also be the case with the construction of a new society, freeed from all forms of exploitation and oppression, a land without awe. It's not capitalism, but socialism and communism, the future of humanity.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. "30 years ago, the peoples trapped behind the Iron Curtain finally succeeded - something their grandparents and parents could not have dreamed of: breaking the wall of communism proclaimed unbreakable. Let us call it the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Velvet Revolution or the Revolution, and the fall of communism in Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and East Germany marked the beginning of a new era. At the same time, it is saddening that the atrocities of communism to this day - 30 years after the overthrow of communism and 75 years after mass abductions into gulags - are still disproportionately little discussed. Yet the Communists destroyed the entire life of our grandparents' generation, their present was stolen, there was no family behind the Iron Curtain that did not suffer the horror of communism. It is therefore disappointing that Western Europe is still refraining from treating the crimes of communism with sufficient weight. It is necessary to know this period of central and eastern European history and to keep its memory alive in order to understand the contemporary reality of post-communist nations. The peoples of Central and Eastern Europe have a very strong commitment to independence and freedom, because even in the history of the 20th century, freedom has had to be fought hard. They did so in 1956, 1968 and 1989.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today we pay homage to the Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia. Unfortunately, bloody revolutions followed, as was the one in December 1989 in my country, Romania. Communism was defeated in the Eastern countries, with sacrifices, at the cost of the lives of some countrymen. Rights and freedom of movement, freedom of expression, the right to choose have been gained, but we still have a lot to do to improve the lives of European citizens in eastern countries. Eastern countries, citizens need a safe life in their country. The European institutions must treat all European citizens equally and fairly, no matter what country they live in. I wish to pay tribute to the heroes of my country and in their memory, but also on behalf of the citizens of my country. I will fight for European values and principles, based on respect for human rights. I will continue in this mandate to fight for equal treatment, without double standard, for a decent standard of living and for the security of all citizens.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Velvet Revolution and the fall of the Berlin Wall, the 30th anniversary of which we are celebrating, are one of the key moments in the history of 20th-century Europe and symbols of its unification. However, in commemorating those events, let us remember that the beginning of the changes that ultimately led to the fall of the Iron Curtain was initiated a few months earlier in Poland, during the Round Table and the elections on 4 June 1989. The political changes that then commonly referred to as the Autumn of Nations in Europe gave an important impetus to the process of European integration, leading both to enlargement and deepening.  On the one hand, German unification has opened the way for accession to the Communities for the new Member States of Central and Eastern Europe, Polish. On the other hand, the signing of the Maastricht Treaty and the establishment of the European Union have marked a new stage in the process of creating an ever closer union between European societies.  Thus, by cultivating the memory of all these past events, let us remember that they should inspire the Member States to reach an agreement and find an effective way to achieve a vision of a united Europe in the near future.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Thirty years ago, protesters filled the streets of Prague. The aspiration for freedom had reached the Czech capital a few days after the fall of the Berlin wall. This anniversary reminds us that in a democracy, the right to demonstrate and to protest peacefully is more vital than ever. Most of all it enables the younger generation, but also others, to mobilise support for an alternative way of doing things. A vibrant civil society and pluralistic media are central in an open society, just like public participation in the democratic process. As a result, governments become accountable. The Velvet Revolution showed how this can be done even in the transition from an authoritarian to an open society. The values that it asserted are now proclaimed all over a Europe where citizens travel and cross borders easily and freely. So, democratic features like an open society, accountability in governance, pluralism in information and debate, social justice are perhaps taken too much for granted. Yet, extremism persists in Europe. The values we hold are not self-evident and should be defended vigorously.

name: Loránt Vincze (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 30th anniversary of the Velvet Revolution: the importance of the struggle for freedom and democracy in Central and Eastern Europe for the historic union of Europe, Madam President! 1989 was a privileged year in Central and Eastern Europe. The wall collapsed, unnaturally separated the two halves of the continent, and communism collapsed with it. A free world and a united Europe would not exist in its present form if tens of thousands of young people and adults had not taken to the streets of Berlin, Prague, Bratislava, Timisoara and Bucharest. They demanded change: freedom of speech, free expression, free and equal elections. Many gave their lives, others risked their own safety and that of their families. Let's remember the brave. Since then, a generation has grown up with no direct experiences of a divided world and I hope they never will experience it. The 30th anniversary is a warning to us that our "European life", living in democracy, prosperity and peace, is not a matter of course. The freedom acquired is not forever and the rights acquired may be threatened. So let us take care of our democracy, our freedom. It's up to us, all of us!

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the current actions of the Russian Federation against Lithuanian judges, prosecutors and investigators involved in the investigation of the tragic events of 13 January 1991 in Vilnius (2019/2938 (RSP)). Once again, I would like to take a moment to point out that requests for spontaneous speeches and blue cards can be made both by the traditional procedure and electronically.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by underlining that the case that we are discussing here, as reported upon recently in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) by our Lithuanian colleagues, is a matter of great concern to the Council. I understand you will express your concern on the issue in a resolution later this week. We have already discussed this matter at the June session of the Justice and Home Affairs Council earlier this year.  The issue of the possible abuse of Interpol alerts is not new. We all remember the case of journalists with dual nationality who were arrested in 2017 on the basis of Interpol red notices. The issue was regularly raised and discussed at the half-yearly meetings of the EU Justice and Home Affairs senior officials with Interpol, with the aim of exploring possible improvements to the then existing Interpol systems and review mechanisms. A number of steps have been taken by Interpol since then, including the creation of a dedicated law enforcement task force to review the red notices. Continuous efforts in this direction are of great importance to protect the rights of our citizens, ensuring that an effective redress mechanism is in place to prevent the abuse of red notices for political reasons.  We also have to emphasise that an Interpol red notice alone cannot be the basis for a decision to extradite a person. That decision will still be subject to a judicial review. Inside the EU, this review falls solely within the competence of the Member States. All that said, it’s clear that we must keep monitoring this issue.  The Member States of the EU, when acting together, have a strong voice at Interpol and we should use it to make sure that the system of red notices is used only for its legitimate purpose – that is to help us arrest dangerous criminals, not political opponents.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss this topic here today. On 12 November, the Lithuanian Minister for Justice spoke in the European Parliament’s Committee for Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs about the case. He informed the Committee that Lithuania had already raised its concerns in the European Network of Councils for the Judiciary (ENCJ).  What we see today is that clearly the events that took place in 1991 still have effects in our Union. The Commission expresses its support and solidarity with Lithuania, one of the EU Member States, for the attacks its judiciary has faced from a neighbouring third country. Lithuania has been constantly targeted by Russian disinformation efforts and a wide array of false narratives have been employed to this end. The present case is not an exception. As proven in the work of the EU Strategic Communication Task Force, Kremlin media have been, and continue to be, engaged in a process of historical revisionism. The events of 13 January 1991 have been portrayed by Russian disinformation activities as a conflict between Lithuanians, removing from the picture the crimes committed under the USSR.  Historical revisionism has been a core part of the Russian disinformation activities. The revisionism serves the purpose of discrediting or undermining the Lithuanian statehood sovereignty justice system and rule of law. Any attack against the judiciary of an EU Member State is an attack against the rule of law of the whole European Union. The Lithuanian judges and prosecutors are judges and prosecutors of the European Union. We strongly believe in the importance of letting Lithuania’s justice system conduct its work in full independence. We need to protect the integrity of our judicial system. The European Commission stands in support of an independent judiciary, without which the Union cannot function. As the Commission underlined in its communication published in July this year on strengthening the rule of law within the EU, upholding the rule of law in the Union is, and must remain, a key objective for all.

name: Rasa Juknevičienė
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, we are considering a question that is important and not only for my country. The Russian Federation has opened criminal proceedings against judges and prosecutors of Lithuania – it means, of the European Union.  In January 1991, the Soviet Government used military force in its attempt to remove the legitimate government in Lithuania. As a result of the military aggression, 14 civilians were killed and more than 800 were injured. This year in March, the Lithuanian court passed a judgment. Former Soviet Union officials were found guilty of war crimes, crimes against humanity and of aggression against Lithuania. The Russian Federation did not cooperate in the case. In total, almost 300 legal assistance requests were sent to the Russian institutions. No replies have been received, or requests were rejected.  Criminal proceedings by the Russian Federation against officers who administered justice in this case is the new tool of hybrid warfare against the EU. We understand how the political system is being attacked. We must understand and state openly that we see how the judiciary of the EU is being targeted. Yes, it is another attack on democracy, which is the main target of Putin’s regime. We must send a clear signal from this Parliament that hybrid attacks against EU judiciary will not be tolerated.  Today we have Lithuanian judges and prosecutors who may face politically motivated persecution. Tomorrow it may be another officer, anywhere in the EU, who deals with any case where the Kremlin denies its citizens’ involvement. I invite you, colleagues, to support the resolution. We will vote on it on Thursday.

name: Juozas Olekas
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Dear colleagues, the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary are the values of our European Parliament, the European Union. I witnessed that tragic Soviet aggression of 13 January 1991. I saw those unarmed, wounded and wounded civilians, and as a doctor, I treated some of them. After a long trial – long because Russia, as a Successor to the Soviets, did not cooperate with Lithuanian law enforcement – after the court's decision, another blow to Russia's democracy was the opening of criminal proceedings against judges, prosecutors and investigators. What will be the next or dutch law enforcement investigation into the MH17 tragedy, or will UK investigators investigating the poisoning of The Scrapaliai? Now is our moment when we have to respond. The European Judicial Network has given its opinion, they support the judges of the European Union, and I therefore call for support and support for the resolution tabled.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – President of the sitting, honourable Representative of Finland, Representative of the Commission, colleagues, almost 30 years after Lithuania's liberation from the occupation of the Soviet Union, the younger generation of Lithuanian citizens is inexperienced in captivity. However, this generation is well aware of Lithuania's path to freedom and independence, and most importantly the price of freedom. Every morning on the 13th of January, classes in Lithuanian schools begin by lighting commemorative candles in tribute to those who, in January 1991, were unarmed against Soviet tanks. Then we lost 14 defenders of freedom, hundreds were injured. Two young people, aged just 17, were among those who died, Darius and Ignas. The families and relatives of them and the others who died have been waiting for historical justice for years. Unfortunately, the vast majority of convicted perpetrators are hiding in Russia and Belarus. It is regrettable that, thirty years after the judgment of the Lithuanian court on 13 January, we once again felt the insidious efforts of the Russian authorities to discredit the defenders of freedom and prosecute those who defended them. I invite you to the act of political solidarity, because the history of lithuanian judges, prosecutors and investigators persecuted by Russia can easily be repeated in other European democracies when deciding on the protection of democracy and freedoms.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Thank you, Honourable President, honourable Minister, Commissioner, colleagues. It is deplorable – in this way one word could describe the actions of the Russian Federation against the law enforcement of Lithuania. The Kremlin is so accustomed to manipulating the Russian legal system that it cannot comprehend that the courts in democratic states are independent. Russia, run by Putin, has not only bothered to help investigate the crimes of January 13, but on the contrary, he is at the rule of law and is looking for tools to spread disinformation. This attack is an attack on all the judges of democratic countries and must be strongly condemned. If we remain silent, we will create the illusion that the Kremlin can continue to manipulate and try to influence the legal systems of our countries. I hope that by voting on the resolution, we will send a clear and non-ambiguous signal to the Kremlin that such politically motivated attacks are intolerable.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I stand by Lithuanians. I pay tribute to the courage of the Lithuanian judges giving the ruling in the 13 January case. It was the most thorough investigation and court proceedings in Lithuanian history. Fourteen people killed; innocent people killed; more than 800 heavily wounded. It was a war crime and a crime against humanity and a Russian probe against both the prosecutors and the judges is absolutely unacceptable. We have to support Lithuania strongly in this case.

name: Andrius Kubilius (PPE).
text: – Madam President, being also Lithuanian, I would like to stress that this is not a purely Lithuanian issue. It is an EU-wide issue because all of us are facing the same new challenge. Our rule of law systems can be attacked openly by the Russian Federation and this is an attack against basic EU values.  The Kremlin wants to test the capability of the EU to defend its rule of law system against an open attack. It’s not a secret interference like they do in our elections. It’s an open attack, which demands an open and direct response from this Parliament. If we fail to give such a response we shall, of course, be inviting the Kremlin to use the same attack against other EU Member States. So I’m grateful to the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council that all of them are standing strong in the defence of the European value of the rule of law, even if only one, Lithuania, is being attacked for the time being. It reminds me of 1989 when we were repeating to our neighbours, ‘for your freedom and our freedom’.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The rule of law is the foundation of every modern democracy. It is also one of the eu's founding principles. However, it is not only within the EU acquis that the rule of law plays a fundamental role, but also in addition to democracy and human rights, the rule of law is one of the three pillars of the Council of Europe and is explicitly listed in the preamble to the ECHR, which Russia has also signed up to. The Russian action against lithuanian judges, investigators and prosecutors who have been active in the legal process surrounding the tragic events of 13 January 1991 is contrary to the rule of law and the standards of international cooperation. It also raises serious questions about the independence of the Russian judiciary. The Russian Government and its President Putin are once again showing that it does not shy away from using authoritarian means to achieve its objectives, inside and outside Russia, as in this case in Lithuania. We must continue to press for the Russian Government and the Russian authorities to respect the rule of law and stop using courts for political pressure.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as former Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic, I want to express my solidarity with Lithuanian judges and prosecutors. The attack on lithuanian justice is an attack on European justice. It is right – and I thank the Institutions of the European Union – that we are acting so clearly. Clear political condemnation of this Russian attack must be accepted. In its negotiations with Russia, the Commission needs to make this clear that this is an attack on us Europeans, on the European Union. Above all, justice ministers and interior ministers of the Member States of the European Union need to do their erms within Interpol to ensure that the principles of an international arrest warrant cannot be abused. This is a subject that has been debated at the level of european ministers of interior and justice for a long time, and now it is being seen again in this case. Let us do our utmost to ensure that efforts to prosecute and abuse international crime through a Euro-screen are not used to prosecute and abuse politically motivated persons.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am standing here as former Minister of Justice of the Kingdom of Spain, but also as current Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs of this European Parliament in which the Lithuanian Minister of Justice presented the case not only of harassment, but prosecution against judges and public prosecutors. And believe me, there is a strong majority in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs which stands for fundamental rights, democracy, rule of law, and values and principles, in which the independence of the judiciary, impartial judges and autonomy of public prosecutors are an outstanding principle – a founding principle of the very foundation of the European Union.  That is why I think we must care about these judges and public prosecutors being prosecuted for having fulfilled their jurisdictional role, which is completely unacceptable. We stand by the Lithuanian judges as we stand by European values and founding principles.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I also stand in solidarity with the Lithuanian people and the judiciary and the prosecutors. An attack on the independence and integrity of the prosecutorial roles of any democratic state in the European Union is an attack on our basic fundamental principles and freedoms. I remember in 1989, it was a huge historic moment in the context of the Berlin Wall falling, coming down, and the hope and aspirations of millions of people on the eastern side of that wall being fulfilled. But the idea that we now can have the Russian Federation intimidating and threatening a judiciary which went about its lawful duty in 1991, in the context of shooting of innocent civilians, is an outrageous attack and it does indicate that we must be forever vigilant in ensuring the rule of law is upheld and we must never be afraid to call it out, even if it is when threatening neighbours and bigger countries are trying to bulldoze and bully smaller countries. I want to stand here in solidarity with the Lithuanian people, my colleagues in this Parliament, but, as importantly, with the rule of law across the entire continent. It must be supported and upheld.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I, too, would like to express my deep solidarity with both our Member State lithuania and, of course, its institutions and citizens. At the same time, I would like to say that this case has two levels for me. One is the issue of abuse of international criminal law, or the law linking it to Interpol, and secondly, it is also an important further test for me from the Russian Federation as far as it can go. I would like to thank the Commissioner here, because I think she has named both pages very clearly. It is clear that there must be a clear reversal of the entire European Union to the Interpol authorities in order to stop this abuse, and secondly, we must also resist the spread of fake news and revisionism, which is being disseminated by some media. I think democracy must defend itself. And it is important that the media that is subject to or disseminates this disinformation simply follow clear sanctions in the event of repeated abuses of this system. We have freedom of speech, but even that has limits.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, colleagues. The tragic events of 13 January 1991 marked the history of Lithuania with the blood and loss of the Lithuanian people. This is the price paid by our nation for freedom and liberation from the forced Soviet occupation. On January 13th in the case of war crimes, persons convicted of crimes against humanity who participated in the organized aggression in Lithuania. Therefore, Russia's actions aimed at launching prosecution proceedings against judges, prosecutors, investigators are another direct attempt to rewrite history and deny the war crimes committed in Lithuania. This is an unjustified interference in the judicial independence of an independent European Union country and a blared attempt to compromise the principle of the rule of law. The European Union must show solidarity with Lithuania and ensure that Russia's illegal actions do not violate the fundamental principles of the European Union and prevent any illegal attempt by Russia to compromise the independence of the judicial system of a country of the European Union.

name: Liudas Mažylis (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I assume the nowadays behaviour of Russia is one beyond any limits. It brutally touches European values such as rule of law and an independent judiciary. Moreover, the intent to use international institutions such as Interpol for prosecuting independent judges. Just to remind you of the tragic events of January 1991, it was carefully planned military Soviet aggression against the newly established Lithuania which led to loss of lives and hundreds injured. Now, after almost three decades, already independent judiciary is a target. It is unacceptable and I invite you to support the resolution and to vote in favour of it.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to repeat in this place again that the Commission expresses its support and solidarity with Lithuania whose judiciary has faced attacks from a neighbouring third country. As has rightly been said here, it is not only a threat against Lithuanian judges and prosecutors, it is not just not only an attack against Lithuania, it’s an attack against the European Union because also the Lithuanian judges and prosecutors are European ones.  The discussions here today underline once more the importance of the work we are undertaking on the protection of the rule of law within our Union. You mentioned here also the aspect of disinformation distributed by the pro-Kremlin media. I can confirm that the new Commission will work intensively on the Action Plan on Democracy, which contains a chapter related to the fight against disinformation and fake news, where I plan to come with proportionate and necessary measures to fight effectively against the disinformation which is considered to be a part of hybrid threats against the EU.  Today’s discussions remind us that we, as a Union, must remain vigilant regarding any undue attack from foreign countries on our citizens, on our elections, on our democracy. So once again, I very much welcome that this Chamber will discuss this issue and I want to thank you for the possibility to take part in the debate here.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I listened attentively to this exchange of views and to the concerns expressed. Let me say that the Lithuanian case is our common case. The Finnish Presidency is committed to the rule of law. We are committed to monitoring this important topic and we shall make sure that it is regularly addressed, in particular during EU meetings of senior officials with Interpol. The Presidency stands ready to explore, with Interpol, what support the EU and the Member States can deliver to avoid possible abuses, and is ready to inform the European Parliament on the outcome of these discussions. I would also like to thank you very warmly for this very topical and important debate.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 28 November 2019.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 172 of the CRP).

name: Eugen Tomac (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my intervention today is about Brexit. I think it is one of the biggest challenges for the European Union brexit since the Union was founded and in my view I think it is a very clear demonstration that populist forces and irresponsible politicians in the European Union remain a threat to us.  But beyond the political, economic and trade effects most hit by Brexit will be European citizens in the UK. They need our support and protection. It is the obligation of Parliament and the Commission to report in real time any slippage, any violation of the labour rights of our citizens. I note that there are more than three hundred thousand Romanian citizens working in the UK.  I also believe that it is essential that we do not accept any compromise affecting the status of our citizens in the UK, but we must also not unfairly penalise the British who have chosen to operate in one of the countries of the European Union. Our founding principles must also prevail in the face of these challenges. Only then can we hope that Britain will one day give up the way out of the European Union.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, energy security for the European Union must be a priority. The energy system of the countries of the European Union depends to a large extent on the import of natural gas and oil, we all know that. It is also known that the main gas supplies to Europe are made from Russia or via Russia from Caspian countries.  However, we have energy resources in the European Union. The Black Sea is one of the major stakes of global competition for energy resources. The Black Sea can be a chance for the European Union's energy security. Romania must be supported in the exploitation of gas and oil in the Black Sea. There are gas reserves of nearly 100 billion m3, according to estimates. The European Union must be interested in these resources, managed fairly, efficiently, within the European Union.  Romania has about 80% of the total area of 12,200 km2 of sovereign exploitation rights, following the trial at the International Court of Justice in The Hague. That is why I would like to draw attention and raise the alarm for the European institutions to support Romania in gas exploitation and in connectivity for gas transport in European corridors.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Madam President! I'm 30. According to the statistics, I'm not supposed to be young anymore, but I still think of her as young, or at least a representative of the younger generations here, that's for sure. However, this does not mean that I am not aware of the importance of intergenerational solidarity. On the contrary, because if we are a young future, it does not mean that you are an older past. You're the present. And what do we want for generations? A better future without compromising the present.  Demographic change is Europe's biggest challenge and that is why social policy is key. I know that a lot of this depends on individual countries, but we can do so much. And I myself have met with representatives of the Slovenian Association of Pensioners, i will, i will continue to go out on the field, after all, my father is quite freshly retired. What's the key to them? Material and financial security, investment in infrastructure, learning digitisation. I also believe that you are aware of the importance of such platforms, so I would ask you to support the intergroup on demographic change and solidarity between generations.

name: Aurelia Beigneux (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, according to an IPCC report, 300 million people will be affected over the next 30 years by rising seas, which is a consequence of global warming and melting ice. It is estimated that a two-metre rise in sea level is entirely possible by the end of the century and that it will cause a considerable decline in coastlines and will inevitably lead to population displacement. This climate and ecological disaster augurs future disasters in our landscapes and ecosystems, with potentially disastrous economic, human and social consequences. It is clear to lead to exiles and serve as a pretext for mass immigration. I am of course particularly concerned about the thousands of kilometres of coastline in metropolitan France and overseas that will suffer this maritime overflow and the worsening of floods, among other natural disasters. At best, this phenomenon must be stopped. At worst, it must be anticipated and prepared.

name: Helmut Geuking (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to take this opportunity to call on you to collectively bring 30 million children out of poverty in Europe. Help us introduce an additional child benefit. Our children of Europe have a right to do so. Financing is not, in fact, a problem through refinancing. By the way, it is one of the best economic promotions. Europe's families need this money, will spend it, bring it to the money cycle and boost the economy. This will give us higher tax revenues, more productivity and additional, secure jobs. Demographic change shows that a Europe without families does not exist. Paying lip service, such as the Children's Guarantee, does not really help us. Together we must create a Europe of families. Let us start with child benefit.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, job insecurity is a pest affecting young and less young people and has serious repercussions on their working lives, but also on future pensions. This precariousness has known causes: low salaries, unregulated hours, either by shifts, by overload of working hours and by mechanisms such as time banks; non-stable employment links that do not protect workers in the event of illness or unemployment, for example such as research grants, traineeships, green receipts, which deprive workers of social support; digital platforms that, under the mask of modernity, deprive their workers of rights.  Precariousness has entered the lexicon and into the lives of workers and the unemployed and tends to be normalized. For example, the proportion of temporary workers in my country is higher than the European average. It is difficult to have labor rights or enter a career, and even those who are in the career see obstacles to progression. The European Union promotes this path. For us, precariousness and the reduction of labour rights are not an inevitability, they are an option that will always be opposed on our part.

name: Claire Fox (NI).
text: – Madam President, I just wanted to salute the activists for democracy who have just won an unprecedented number of seats in the Hong Kong elections. It was a massive turnout, what an exhilarating result! After tens of thousands have taken to the streets to fight for their freedoms against violent clampdowns it’s so inspiring to see that support now demonstrated at the ballot box. But I note that many in power and authority in Hong Kong and China try and explain these results by saying the young activists are being misinformed by fake news, misled by extremists. Does it sound familiar? I hope colleagues here at Parliament won’t make the mistake you made with the UK when we voted Brexit by telling the Hong Kong freedom fighters that they voted the wrong way, go back and vote again. We democrats should stick together in solidarity and recognise that whether it’s in Hong Kong or the UK, democracy and freedom are worth fighting for and should be celebrated and congratulated, not condemned.

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, southern Portugal, particularly in the Alentejo and Algarve regions, is facing an extreme drought. A few days ago the mayor of Monchique, an Algarve municipality, defended in Brussels a European contingency plan to help deal with this situation. This plan may go through water efficiency programs, dam construction or the installation of desalination plants.  Aware that the lack of water is a scourge for many European regions I subscribe to and reinforce this call for action. It is urgent that the European Union defines and implements measures to deal more quickly with these and other phenomena. The fight against climate change is not just about the adoption of preventive measures, however crucial they may be. It is also essential to respond to the effects we already face today.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Madam President! The protection of minority rights is not a burden on the majority for minority privileges, but a protection of the diversity that enriches the European family.  We must be concerned both for the direct and indirect threats to the rights of minorities that are taking place in the Member States.  I am particularly concerned about constitutional amendments to reduce the number of seats in both houses of the Italian Parliament. These changes pose a serious threat to the political participation and representation of minorities, such as the Indigenous Slovenian national community in the Republic of Italy.  There is a real risk that the obligations under the Italian Constitution and the Protection Act 2001 for Slovenes in Italy, which require the facilitated election of representatives of the Slovenian community, will be indirectly violated. I therefore call on the competent italian colleagues and my Italian colleagues from this town to draw attention to the importance of protecting the rights of minorities and respecting European values, even in this case.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I raise the issue of funding in Ireland in the context of the Western Corridor. It’s a motorway project from Letterkenny in the north-west of the country right down to Cork, in the south-west of the country. A lot of that was EU-supported over many, many years, but there are large sections of this particular motorway which have not been completed yet.  This is an integral part of the development of Ireland in the context of making sure we have proper structural and regional balance in place; that all the activity isn’t just funded into the capital in Dublin, and that the south and south-west in particular would have opportunities to grow and expand and increase its population; and the road structure and investment that is required from Limerick to Cork and the north-ring road in Cork is a critical infrastructural part that is required to ensure we have strong regional balance across the island of Ireland. So I’m calling on people to support me in my efforts to get the Irish Government, with assistance from the European Union, to complete this integral infrastructural development.

name: André Rougé (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to French Polynesia, a French territory in the Pacific that is paradoxically not part of the European Union. Thanks to Polynesia, France enjoys the deterrent force and nuclear independence, and we are infinitely grateful to it. As a result of the tests in the area, which could eventually be combined with the discharge of contaminated water from Fukushima into the Pacific Ocean and the U.S. tests in the Marshall Islands, some of our compatriots have been affected by particularly serious radio-induced diseases. Within the framework of its treaty powers, the European Union must work with France to protect our Fellow Polynesians and help find them appropriate treatments. France is part of the European Union, although the National Gathering has reservations. As such, our compatriots in French Polynesia cannot be regarded as second-class citizens and should receive, on the part of the European institutions, assistance commensit to the consideration they deserve.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, this year marks the 100th 100th of the infamous Neue stage. This is the peace treaty that ended for Bulgaria The First World War. He is disgraceful and should make all the heirs of Clemence, the other Western European prime ministers, ashamed. This contract divides relatives, divides families, divides houses, divides yards, divides even graves. If you have not seen what a divided grave is, come to the village of Petachentsi, come to the village of Strezimirovtsi, come and be ashamed. Because the Neuilly Dikta is a disgrace. It is a disgrace to those who claimed to be for self-determination, but allowed their outlaw allies from Belgrade to occupy the bulgarian lands, to divide territories. It's a disgrace. A disgrace to remember. On this date, on the 27th, the day of the Bulgarian victory, by the way, we say: "Down With Neui", we say: "The western outskirts must return to Bulgaria", we say: "Long live the single and indivisible Bulgarian homeland".

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in one minute, I would like to address an issue that has long been at the centre of our concern, particularly in the Czech Republic, on the issue of conflicts of interest. This conflict of interest and regulation, of course, has a general impact, it must be a system to prevent it. I must also recognise that this regulation affects more people in the European Union. But I would like to address the impact that is on the Czech Prime Minister, I am glad that Commissioner Jourová is also there. I am particularly interested in the issue of the publication of the final report, which should be presented by the European Commission. I understand that the draft report has not been published by the European Commission, it is a principle of a certain confidentiality. However, I believe that the publication of the final report is entirely in the public interest and I would very much like the Commissioner, who has transparency in her portfolio, to take up this issue. At the same time, I would like to point out that the position of the European Ombudsman, O'Reilly, with whom I had the opportunity to speak, was clearly in favour of publication. So I firmly believe that even the new European Commission will respect the right to information from European citizens.

name: Adriana Maldonado López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I wanted to highlight an issue that is beginning to happen in the European Union, which is that more and more people in the European Union are spending hours playing online. In the case of Spain, approximately 1.5 million people a day play virtually and we are seeing that the profile of the person playing is not only that of the male from 25 to 45 years old, but more and more young people and more women are being immersed in this type of online games.
