The European Commission must therefore also put the issues of online gambling at the heart of its digital political agenda, because it must be remembered that online gaming is not currently within the digital single market. The European Commission must therefore begin to assess, first of all, the recommendations it made to Member States on online gambling in 2014 and, secondly, it is important that the European Union regulates online gambling, because it is a scourge that is reaching society and every day we see how younger on our continent they are affected by this serious problem.

name: Илхан Кючюк (Renew).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, I take the floor on behalf of the DPS delegation to the European Parliament. The occasion is sad - the election of the extreme nationalist Valery Simeonov as Vice-President of the Bulgarian Parliament. And if you're still asking yourself who I'm talking about, then let me remind you.  This is the person who pushed elderly women on the border with Turkey, came to vote or just to see their relatives. His motive was one - they are ethnically different. He called Roma mothers to give birth like bitches. He called mothers of disabled children "armchair women" with "supposedly sick children." In any other European country, this cynic would have long been in the history of politics. But in Bulgaria it is rewarded and empowered. It is even sadder that this is done with the support of the Bulgarian parties that are members of the EPP and PES. I also have questions for the European Commission. Mrs Jourová, how will the Commission ensure the protection of the principles of tolerance and human dignity of all European citizens enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union? We'il ask them these questions and look for our own answers.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to a very concrete, and not the first, but yet another aberration of the European Union's migration policy. In particular, Member State Belgium is currently inundated with asylum applications from El Salvador – indeed. Salvadorans are allowed to travel visa-free to the Schengen zone. A wide front door is now being made of one loophole, which is why I am calling for the immediate adoption by this European Parliament of a motion for a resolution which I tabled with the intention of immediately removing El Salvador, but also Guatemala and Venezuela from the list of countries exempted from visa requirements.

name: Mazaly Aguilar (ECR).
text: – (start of off-microphone intervention) ...  it is impossible to explain the recent court ruling condemning the greatest plot of political corruption in the history of Spain and the European Union, and I am referring to the employment regulation files in Andalusia carried out by the Spanish Socialist Party, which ruled in this region of my nation for almost forty years. Six hundred and eighty million euros, which were to be used for people who, unfortunately, had lost their jobs, went fraudulently to the purchase of votes and to the enrichment of a number of people and companies linked to the Spanish Socialist Party. The sentence gives its first and last name and, among the convicted, there are two presidents at the national level of the Spanish Socialist Party, who were also presidents of the Junta de Andalucía. For the sake of our democracy and out of respect for our institutions, I ask you to help us isolate the most corrupt party in the whole of the European Union. All those who look the other way are contributing to the fed-up of a society that feels defrauded and deceived by corruption, lying and hypocrisy. Unfortunately, this will not be the first or last sentence. Others will also affect the Socialist Party and the management of European funds for training. And here we will be to continue to report it.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, we know that migration is one of the main topics discussed in the European Union today. However, apart from external migration and migration from third countries that are much discussed, we must not forget those internal migrations, which are particularly important migration between central and eastern European countries on one side and countries in Western and Northern Europe on the other. These migrations can be a big problem, especially for countries like Croatia, which have just entered and are only now encountering this, especially for rural, less developed areas from which many young people, many experts, leave, especially in those areas where they are competitive in the labour market such as health care.  The only way to combat this brain drain is development, and there is no development in countries like Croatia without cohesion policy and European funds. Unfortunately, in this regard, the European Commission's proposal to reduce funding for cohesion policy is not a good message. It speaks out against the solidarity on which the European Union is founded and I think we should oppose this.  In other words, yes to cohesion, yes to increasing funding, yes to solidarity, not to cut funding.

name: Sándor Rónai (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Eur 2.5 billion, or nearly HUF 700 billion, was fined by the European Commission to the Hungarian Government for improperly using the aid. They cheated on the selection of developments, public procurement and accounting as if there was no tomorrow. And Viktor Orban just tugged. There are no fidesz colleagues in the room right now, and there is no need to fear impeachment or investigations, and there is no talk of them. This case shows that the illiberal lords of Eastern Europe care nothing about the support of the European Union. Cohesion money, agricultural subsidies, too, land in the pockets of friends, relatives and oligarchs. It is time for the Commission and the Council to finally draw the right conclusion. Orban and those like him must stop. Theft must be stopped and we must be pro-European politicians, brave. A direct support system should be established and launched in order to ensure that these grants reach where they belong: municipalities, small and medium-sized enterprises and NGOs.

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: – Romania became a member of the European Union in 2007. For twelve years we have been a full party in a Union where in theory all countries are equal and yet we are a second-tier country. Romanians and Bulgarians are still being detained at the gates of Europe. Our citizens, European citizens, stand in endless queues when they have to cross the border into Europe. Romanian and Bulgarian companies keep their goods at the border for hours, sometimes even days to be able to enter what should be the common market, which adds additional costs to products in our countries. We are talking about the free movement of European citizens, about the free movement of goods, but this movement is not exactly free for Romanians and For Bulgarians. It has been too many years since we have been recognised as having the right to be included in the Schengen area. How much longer do we have to stay at the gates of Europe? When will the serious discussions about the truly free entry of Romanians and Bulgarians into the united territory of Europe take place?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, these days we are watching the situation in Hong Kong with tension and, of course, we are supporting the students' resistance to the creeping totalitarianism that is spreading from China to that hitherto free region. Thirty years ago, students were also a driving force in Czechoslovakia. It is clear that education and freedom belong together and also a sense of responsibility for what is happening around us. This has always been true everywhere. An educated person who learns certain values is inevitably an enemy of totalitarianism. In Europe and China. I therefore want the European Parliament to make it clear that it is behind the forces that are in Hong Kong and which defend democracy and freedom. I want them to know, both in Hong Kong and China, that the European Parliament recognises the results of municipal elections and that China must also recognise them.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, last week the meeting of the presidents of the nine outermost regions of the European Union belonging to three Member States took place in Brussels: France, Portugal and Spain (Spain for the Canary Islands, the land in which I was born and resided). They're fragmented territories, far away. Most of them are insular and therefore in need of specificities in their policy of maritime, fishing, agricultural and accessibility. But above all, they need support in the multiannual financial framework. Because it is imperative that the co-financing rate, currently set at 85% but threatened with a 70% reduction in the proposal for the next multiannual financial framework, should be maintained, which is seriously detrimental to the support of the public accounts of the outermost regions.  It is imperative that the good intentions of the Commissioner proposed for the Cohesion and Reform Portfolio, Elisa Ferreira, translate into a real budgetary commitment to support these regions, which are the only ones called by name in the Treaties establishing the European Union.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I use this opportunity to draw attention once again to the violent attacks that continue to occur against indigenous peoples dictated by the voracious ness of extractivist sectors, often unresponsive, when not with the connivance of political powers. This is the case in Brazil, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela and other Latin American countries, transformed into the deadliest region for indigenous people stoneware. The recent death of Paulo Paulino of the Guajajara tribe in Brazil or the attack on the NASA community in southwestern Colombia, in which five people died are just recent examples that illustrate an unacceptable reality. Violence, intimidation, harassment and forced displacement of indigenous communities are increasingly common. The European Union must be proactive in defending these communities. The United Nations declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples and ILO Convention No. 169 are clear in the rules and limits they establish. We have to use the instruments at our fingertips to ensure that they are fulfilled.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, at its foundation, democracy is about freedom and with that should come equality for all men and women to use the franchise at the ballot box to change their lives.  The stunning landslide victory for pro-democracy candidates in the Hong Kong local council elections at the weekend is testament to that. After months of unrest, violent clashes and unlawful actions by the police towards protesters, the electorate spoke and they do not want to be ruled by, or from, China. This is particularly true for young people, who often led the protests whilst coming under attack from the security forces, and with the siege at PolyU being particularly worrying and, as yet, still unresolved. I believe we must safeguard the Sino-British Joint Declaration, which is key to the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong.  Finally, I’d like to thank the 50 plus MEPs who signed my letter to Federica Mogherini on the issue. I look forward to the Commission’s response, outlining their engagement with all sides to ensure that peace and fundamental freedoms are maintained.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am pleased that today, including in the European Parliament, we have commemorated the round 30th anniversary of the Velvet Revolution and democratic change, especially in Central Europe. And I am even more glad that not only superlatives have been said, but that we have tried to look from another side and we have also pointed out what has not yet been achieved. However, I did not want to talk about these very things at the time, but I would like to stress that it is the Velvet Revolution that has allowed all these democratic changes to become part of the European Union. However, the EU is still not perfect either, and there are still different differences, whether socially or regionally, between the population and between regions within the EU. We must do everything we can to ensure that the EU is armed not only with good policies, but also with enough money to eliminate these differences. Otherwise, we will not thrive in the fight against those extremist forces that describe the EU as evil, as well as democracy.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes this item.
